163.Input.res_a: It sounds like you're feeling a bit overwhelmed about the homework assignments. Let's break it down together. We can discuss what specific areas you're struggling with and how we can make the tasks more manageable. I'll also review the previous assignments with you to ensure you understand what's expected.
163.Input.res_b: That’s a pretty common concern. Let’s come up with ways to help support your work this week. Regarding doing all of the homework correctly, although we want to be on the same page, honest mistakes invariably create useful learning opportunities. It might sound weird, but part of me actually wants you to make some mistakes because we often learn best from them.
163.ori_text: I’m worried about my thoughts about my friend. He is very depressed and has recently been self-harming by starving himself. He is seeing a therapist and getting help. At first I tried to help and it wasn’t easy as I was feeling depressed but i always put him first. But, I thought about what would happen if he killed himself and now I want him to do it, I want him to die. This is a horrible thing to feel.
163.situation: But, I thought about what would happen if he killed himself and now I want him to do it, I want him to die. This is a horrible thing to feel.
163.thoughts: I'm not capable of solving these problems. This situation has no resolution. The only way this situation could improve is by eliminating this friend. There is no other way out. I cannot tolerate the discomfort, worry, guilt, fear, and/or anger about this situation. If I can't help make this better, then no one else can. I don't see a way out so there must not be a way out other than death. I judge myself as a failure. I judge myself for my feelings. It's not okay to feel desperate or angry.

164.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
164.Input.client_statement: [Angry] It’s hard to come up with goals because I’m not really sure what we’re doing in here.
164.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation
164.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the goals and tasks
164.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize concrete, actionable, and measurable goals
164.Input.res_a: I completely understand your frustration. Let me clarify the purpose of our sessions. We're working together to identify and challenge negative thought patterns and behaviors that are causing you distress. Setting specific, achievable goals will help us focus our efforts and measure progress. Can we start by exploring what you hope to achieve from therapy?
164.Input.res_b: That’s important to hear, and I can see how that might make it hard to come up with goals! Just to clarify, is the uncertainty about therapy in general or the CBT model that we’ve started to introduce? It might seem a bit backward, but identifying potential goals can also inform what we do in here.
164.ori_text: I’m not sure what to say…I feel like I’m going crazy…. I can’t stop reliving my past in my sleep. When I was…young, I was raped on a regular basis by my only guardian (he was not related) and occasionally sold for his self gain……….I thought I could grow out of these nightmares where I remember everything so vividly, but they’re becoming more frequent……….
164.situation: I thought I could grow out of these nightmares where I remember everything so vividly, but they’re becoming more frequent
164.thoughts: I should have been able to fix this by now. I am a failure. I am not as strong as I thought I was. I am weak. I want this to go away without actively working on it. I want this to go away on its own. I am scared to face this head on. I am scared to work on this actively.

165.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
165.Input.client_statement: [Frustrated] Well, I’m not really sure about it, but I guess I’ll give the thought record another shot if you think that’s best.
165.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
165.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Warmly invite the client to discuss their subjective experience
165.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Empathize with the clientʼs thoughts and feelings and invite further disclosure of unhelpful or invalidating occurrences
165.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: “Disarm” the clientʼs negative affect toward you or CBT by finding some truth in their disclosures
165.Input.exe: Exercise: Responding to Therapeutic Alliance Ruptures
165.Input.res_a: Well, we certainly can do one together. However, I get the feeling that maybe you’re just agreeing to do it because I suggested it. Like you’re going along with it but maybe aren’t so sure it makes sense right now? Is that on- or off base?
165.Input.res_b: I appreciate your willingness to give the thought record another try. It’s completely normal to feel frustrated. Let’s explore what might have been challenging before and see if we can adjust the process to make it more effective for you.
165.ori_text: I’m 14 years old and have social anxiety / depression. When I was 5 years old, my father was killed in a car crash. After that, my mother continued to work. When I was 9, my mom and I were in a severe car accident. She broke every bone on the right side of her body and I ruptured my spleen and fractured my leg.
165.situation: I’m 14 years old and have social anxiety / depression. When I was 5 years old, my father was killed in a car crash. When I was 9, my mom and I were in a severe car accident.
165.thoughts: I’m too young to be this messed up. I guess it makes sense considering my dad died in a car accident and then my mom and I were in a serious crash, too. I don’t think things will ever get better. I’m wired to be anxious and depressed forever. Anytime I think we’re going to be okay, something horrible happens. I’m scared I’ll never feel normal. I’m scared about letting my guard down. If I do, my mom could leave and die in an accident. Then, I’d be all alone. Everything is just so scary. I’m scared to try anything new.

166.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
166.Input.client_statement: [Impatient] How long will it take for this to work? I don’t have a lot of time or money.
166.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Explain the logic of how CBT can be used to address concerns
166.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Instill hope for using CBT effectively
166.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Set appropriate expectations for the nature and impact of CBT
166.Input.exe: Exercise: Explaining the Treatment Rationale for Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
166.Input.res_a: I completely understand your concerns about time and resources. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy is a goal-oriented and problem-focused approach that typically yields noticeable progress within a few sessions. The number of sessions needed can vary, but we'll work together to set specific, achievable goals and regularly assess our progress. Our aim is to equip you with practical skills and strategies that you can apply to your daily life, leading to lasting improvements.
166.Input.res_b: That’s an important question that’s somewhat difficult to answer. I realize this might be frustrating to hear, but it depends. This approach to therapy is generally built on a shorter term model that has a track record of effectiveness, but each person is unique. We’ll be monitoring progress at every session and would expect to see improvement by six or eight sessions. If we don’t, we’ll want to discuss whether any changes are needed.
166.ori_text: I have been dating this guy for about three months now. In the beginning of our relationship, everything was perfect and I trusted him whole-heartedly. Up until recently I’ve been very suspicious and my trust just keeps going down. I started to lose trust when finding a text message in his phone from someone calling him babe on Valentines Day. He said it was nothing like that, and I asked to see the rest of the messages from that person but he said no because he thought that would change the dynamics of our relationship and that I am supposed to just trust him, so I let it go. Ever since that occasion it’s been so hard for me to trust him like I did in the beginning. He’s constantly texting some person in his phone and I’m 99% sure it is a female, which does not bother me. But what does bother me is that for some reason I have this gut instinct that this female he is constantly texting is someone he is involved with. When I sit and ponder on that idea I think to myself, He doesn’t even have time to spend with other women, he’s always so busy. But I almost feel like I’m convincing myself because I just have this feeling inside. On top of all of this my mother and a few of my close friends don’t really trust this guy or particularly care for him too which makes it even harder for me as well. I’m wondering how you feel about this situation? Should I end this relationship before I get hurt or wait it out and see if it can really become as good as I thought it could?
166.situation: Up until recently I’ve been very suspicious and my trust just keeps going down. I started to lose trust when finding a text message in his phone from someone calling him babe on Valentines Day. He said it was nothing like that, and I asked to see the rest of the messages from that person but he said no because he thought that would change the dynamics of our relationship and that I am supposed to just trust him, so I let it go.
166.thoughts: I don’t know if I can trust him anymore. He’s obviously hiding things from me. If he wasn’t hiding anything, he’d let me see his phone. He said it would change the dynamics of our relationship, but they’ve already changed cause I don’t feel secure anymore. He told me I’m supposed to just trust him, and even though I tried to let it go, I can’t help myself. I feel like he’s cheating on me.

167.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
167.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I’ve learned some new things. But I still feel tense all the time. I can’t have a conversation with anyone without lashing out. I feel on edge and still can’t really relax.
167.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and transparent stance
167.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Demonstrate openness to explore before determining if a modification is indeed warranted
167.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain consistency with a broad CBT orientation
167.Input.res_a: It's great you're learning new things; that's progress. Let's identify specific triggers and explore strategies to manage them. Remember, it's about small, consistent steps. When you start feeling tense, try deep breathing or brief mindfulness exercises. Over time, these practices can help you feel more at ease in conversations.
167.Input.res_b: I’m glad we’re having this conversation. My sense is that it will be useful to continue following our general plan, but there are some other options that clients find helpful that could help reduce some of your tension and are worth considering. If you’re OK with this, I’d like us to spend the rest of today’s session on some more targeted relaxation strategies.
167.ori_text: From a teen in Australia: I have had a partner for over one year, I cheated on my partner at the very beginning of the relationship then stopped I was loyal to him for a good few months and a few days ago I cheated on him again and I don’t understand why I did it, I didn’t feel anything when I was cheating on him in the moment I was just thinking about him being hurt, angry and confused and I was rather upset when doing it but I kept doing it. I would love to know what y’all think about this because I don’t know what to think and I don’t want any of my friends to think I’m a slut so I’m not going to askthem.
167.situation: Being in a relationship for over a year, experiencing infidelity at the beginning and recently repeating the same behavior despite feeling upset and conflicted about it.
167.thoughts:
I cheated on my partner again, i will never figure this out.
I don't understand why I always do what I do.
I didn't feel anything in the moment.
I was just thinking about him being hurt, angry, and confused.
My friends think I'm a slut.

168.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
168.Input.client_statement: [Panicking] Oh my god . . . Oh my god . . . I’m dying! I can’t breathe! Help me!
168.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Empathically inquire about clientsʼ emotional experience
168.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Actively listen and maintain a supportive tone to clientsʼ emotional disclosures
168.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Model tolerance of affect and an approach orientation to clientsʼ strong emotional experience
168.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Use psychoeducation to support the importance of clients experiencing versus avoiding their emotion and the maladaptive consequences of negative reinforcement
168.Input.res_a: [Speaking calmly, establishing eye contact] Remember that you’re breathing right now, even though it feels like you can’t. Try to just focus on your breathing. We’ll do it together. Just breathe with me. You can do this.
168.Input.res_b: It sounds like you're experiencing a panic attack. Let's take a deep breath together. I'm here to support you, and I want you to know that you're safe. Can you tell me what's going on right now that's making you feel like this?
168.ori_text: About a year ago I had an affair with a girl that I have broken off and had no contact with for said time. I have done everything in my power to prove to my girlfriend that I’m faithful now. Almost on a daily basis she accuses me of doing stuff behind her back to the point that I’m ready to leave her.
168.situation: I have done everything in my power to prove to my girlfriend that I’m faithful now. Almost on a daily basis she accuses me of doing stuff behind her back to the point that I’m ready to leave her.
168.thoughts: She doesn’t believe me no matter what I say or do. I doubt she will ever believe me. This is exhausting. I can’t take it anymore. What’s the point anyway? I’m not cheating. I’ve told her a million times. She still thinks I’m cheating. How many more times can we go around and around? If she doesn’t trust me, then what’s the point of being in a relationship with me? She should just leave me then. Why doesn’t she just leave? I thought she forgave me and we moved on, but she just won’t let it go. She will never let it go.

169.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
169.Input.client_statement: [Angry] You seem so concerned with just finishing what’s on your list before time runs out. I feel like I’m just a plug-and-play client!
169.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
169.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Empathically explore the clientʼs experience of treatment and you
169.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Validate clientsʼ experience and “roll with” versus challenging their resistance
169.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Support clientsʼ autonomy and elicit their motivation for pursuing valued directions
169.Input.res_a: I really appreciate your courage in pointing out this really important feeling. I imagine it has been painful to feel like I’ve lost you in some of the details of the work. Very importantly, I’d really like to change that.
169.Input.res_b: I understand that you feel like you're being treated impersonally. Can you help me understand what would make you feel more heard and understood in our sessions, and how I can tailor my approach to better meet your needs?
169.ori_text: I was fine until 7th grade ended, and then its like my memory jump skips to constantly being worried and miserable. When I was going through 8th grade I reached a point were I decided to work on what was bothering me so I could be better, but thats when I realized I had no idea what was bothering me. Looking back before all of this started though I’m not sure if I ever was fine, when I was younger I never considered any other kids to be my friend really, a lot of adults though. I did eventually move to a place were I kinda grew comfortable with everyone, and while I used to consider that time to be the peak of my life, looking back there were still flags then to. Im not exactly sure when, but between 2nd and 5th grade I developed maladaptive daydreaming, and while I felt fine for some reason little me felt compelled to feel emotional pain, I used to purposefully seek out depressing content to put myself in a bad mood, I honestly still kind of do this. During this time I developed a crush in which I became obsessively and honestly kind of creepily attached to him which drove him away from me in the long run,(this repeated in 7th). Anyways after 5th grade I moved away from that place to somewhere else, I got adjusted and made new friends and everything seemed fine until 7th grade ended. Going into 8th I originally had hope, I hoped I go back and I’d fall back into the old groove of things and everything would be fine, but when I got back it was just more issues. I didn’t trust anyone, every time I was with my friends I just felt alone, and I figured they probably wanted me gone so they could actually have a good time. My anxiety, (that was previously nonexistent), was at its peak, i’d have shooting pains, hypnic jerks, and would frequently fall into states of depersonalization/derealization. I finally came to the conclusion that the way to stop hurting, was to stop caring. I’d repeatedly tell myself, I don’t care about anything, I don’t care about anyone, in hopes that I would believe it, I’m not sure if that had any effect on me, but after 8th grade ended I just stopped caring. I still had symptoms of anxiety and depression, but they were no longer manifesting themselves into physical symptoms. I still felt unwanted by my group of friends so I just stopped hanging out with them. I wouldn’t say I felt happy, but I wasn’t miserable, I was just kind of done I think. Going into high school I still didn’t really have any friends because I was to scared to talk to anyone, and when they made an effort to talk to me, all I could think in response to there advances were one word answers. I started to grow more fearful of the future as I realized that my childhood was running out and I had no idea what I want to do with my life. I know people say pursue a career in your interests but nothing interests me. If I could truly do anything in life, I’d find a secluded area from everyone so I could listen to music and be alone to my fantasy world. I guess that’s kind of were i am now, done, and fearful of the future. I can recognize that not all my thoughts are correct and 90% of the bad things that im convinced everyone feels about me, are probably caused by my anxiety, but even being actively aware of that I still don’t feel any different. I just hope that someday I can be normal, I fear that all I’ll have to remember my teenage years, is me sitting alone in my room listening to music. I wish I could go to social outings and take risks, and have new experiences, and I realize for that to happen I have to take the initiative, but everytime I get handed a chance to do those things I shy away from them because in the moment that all sounds like a terrible idea to me because I much rather be left alone, and its not until later that I regret it. A part of me wonders if this all karma, and I’m actually a bad person, or a narcissist thats suffering the consequences of her actions.
169.situation: This client is struggling with feeling worthless which is leading to unfulfilling social interactions and a poor sense of self.
169.thoughts: I am worthless, nobody wants to be my friend, I am boring, people are better off without me, I am not normal, something is wrong with me, I am not like other people, I have no friends.

170.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
170.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I know the job interview is going to go poorly; they always do.
170.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
170.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
170.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
170.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
170.Input.res_a: How do you typically determine whether or not an interview has gone poorly? Can you think of an instance when, perhaps to your surprise, an interview didn’t go as poorly as you expected?
170.Input.res_b: Let's break down this thought. It sounds like you're predicting a negative outcome based on past experiences. Can you tell me more about what you mean by "they always go poorly"?
170.ori_text: I have been in a relationship with my best friend for five years. We are a great fit in all ways, but he frequently questions my integrity and his self-worth. A few years ago, I took a high paying job as a personal assistant. We were living in a bad neighborhood and I jumped at the opportunity to make more money- without questioning the logistics. It ended up being a personal assistant to a pimp, arranging dates, managing money, and sending out ads for the girls. We talked about what my job would entail, and he was not happy with it, but agreed that we needed the money and it wouldn’t be forever. A few months after I started, my boss forced me to do something not in my job description. In the situation, I feared for my life, so I obliged. I didn’t show up for my shift the next day, hoping it would all just go away and I could find a different job quickly. I started receiving threatening phone calls. My boss demanded all the money he had paid me back ($20,000). He had a copy of my ID and social from the hiring process. He made it very clear that my life was in his hands. I worked as a sex worker for a year and a half to pay him back in full. During that time, my boyfriend found out about it and understandably flipped out. Our marriage plans went out the window, I was forced out of our friend group, and was left to deal with the aftermath alone. That was two years ago, and we are in a much better place now. But for him, marriage still isn’t on the table and his friends haven’t welcomed me back. He says that he often blames himself for not figuring it out sooner, and blames me for not coming to him for help. I try to explain to him that I was scared to involve anyone else for fear of what would happen to them, but he just doesn’t understand why I didn’t go to the cops. I’m afraid this occurrence will always be a stain on my relationship resume with him, and that he will only see his pain of feeling betrayed and cheated on, when that was not my intention. Can we work towards forgiveness? Or am I wasting my time? (From the USA)
170.situation: I have been in a relationship with my best friend for five years. Our bond was strong, built on years of shared experiences and mutual understanding. We complemented each other in every way, and our future together seemed promising. However, our relationship was tested when I made a decision out of desperation without fully considering the consequences.
170.thoughts:
He frequently questions my integrity..
He blames himself for not figuring it out sooner.
He will only see his pain of feeling betrayed and cheated on.

171.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
171.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I’ve been working hard on keeping my drinking under control, but it’s hard. I’m kind of nervous because my friend insists on having his birthday party at the bar this weekend.
171.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and curious stance
171.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Be clear when suggesting a plan of action and expectations
171.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Be positive and supportive of both big and small positive changes
171.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Appeal to relevant core learning concepts, including conditioning, reinforcement, the importance of environment, antecedents, and consequences
171.Input.res_a: Tell me if this is off base, but it sounds like you’re concerned about being around so much alcohol and other people drinking at this party. When we’ve discussed your alcohol use, it seems like there are some specific circumstances that are associated with your drinking. Although we don’t want to cut you off from your friends or any place that might serve alcohol forever, there are situations that are going to be more or less helpful to you. I’m interested in hearing more about your concerns, and I suggest that we brainstorm a plan. How does that sound?
171.Input.res_b: It sounds like you're feeling a bit apprehensive about the upcoming party. That's understandable, given your efforts to manage your drinking. Let's break this down: what specific concerns do you have about attending the party at the bar? Is it the temptation to drink, the social pressure, or something else? By identifying the root of your anxiety, we can start to develop a plan to help you navigate this situation and stay on track with your goals. How does that sound?
171.ori_text: Having the structure of our family to focus on seemed to help my schizophrenic mother hold it together while we were growing up. We saw her first psychotic episode when I was a senior in high school the oldest child. Mom did spend time in state mental hospitals before she was married. My father was a verbally abusive alcoholic.
171.situation: Having the structure of our family to focus on seemed to help my schizophrenic mother hold it together while we were growing up. We saw her first psychotic episode when I was a senior in high school the oldest child.
171.thoughts: Our family structure was probably the only thing that kept my mom stable, but once I was a senior in high school applying to colleges, that’s when everything started falling apart. I think the idea of me leaving home broke her. So, I need to stay with her. If I don’t keep her safe, who will? Our dad isn’t good at taking care of her; he only cares about himself. I’m the only one who can do it. If I don’t, everything will fall apart. My mom needs me. I can’t go to college. I’m stuck here but I love my mom, so I know what I should do.

172.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
172.Input.client_statement: [Curious] I’m not sure about an agenda. With my other therapist, I just kind of talked about whatever was on my mind.
172.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
172.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
172.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
172.Input.res_a: I understand that you're used to a more exploratory approach. In CBT, we use an agenda to ensure we make the most of our time together and tackle specific issues that are bothering you. It's not about restricting what you can talk about, but rather about prioritizing and focusing on what's most important to you. Would you be willing to try setting an agenda for today's session and see how it feels? We can always adjust as needed.
172.Input.res_b: Yes, some therapies are less structured than others. The approach that we’re taking is more on the structured side. Regardless, I want to make sure that we focus on the things that are most important to you. In my experience, it can be helpful to do this in the context of a general plan connected to your goals to keep things on track and continue to move our work forward. If it’s OK with you, I’d like to hear more about your thoughts about being more structured in here.
172.ori_text: I believe that I’ve got a mental illness, and that’s pretty obvious to me. The thing is that i also believe that i want to have one. Can this desire (to want to get worse, or to want to have a mental disorder) be considered as a mental disorder itself?
172.situation: I believe that I want to have a mental illness (or want to get worse).
172.thoughts:
- Something is wrong with me.
- I am sick.
- I am 'crazy.'
- I am not like others.

173.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
173.Input.client_statement: [Hopeless, after completing a progress monitoring measure] I think the scores on the measure you asked me to complete are consistent with my experience so far. It feels like things might actually be getting worse.
173.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and transparent stance
173.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Demonstrate openness to explore before determining if a modification is indeed warranted
173.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain consistency with a broad CBT orientation
173.Input.res_a: It's understandable to feel that way. Let's look at the progress monitoring measure together to understand the details. Remember, fluctuations are normal, and setbacks can provide valuable insights. Your consistent effort is what leads to long-term improvement.
173.Input.res_b: That’s important to acknowledge, even more so because it’s being communicated in multiple ways. I also understand that this might feel discouraging. Let’s revisit our plan and talk about what, specifically, isn’t working and what, if anything, might be working.
173.ori_text: I have a question about seeing therapists. I have read and have been told by friends who have had this come up in therapy that it is not ok to see more than one therapist. I understand in principle, but I have a question. I saw a psychologist off and on for 10 years who was very helpful to me through a number of issues I dealt with. He was very supportive, which I needed, and he knows me very well. I felt i had gone as far as I could with him on problems I was haveing with ADHD problems and problems with schooling. I felt bad for him that I just kept failing to improve. I was referred by my psychiatrist to a cognitive psychologist, and he was helpful to some extent in a different and complementary way.
173.situation: I felt bad for him that I just kept failing to improve.
173.thoughts: I have expectations for myself and if I don't meet those expectations, then I am a failure. If I don't meet those expectations, I should be ashamed and hide. If I don't meet those expectations, I must abandon my relationships even if they are with a professional whose job is to help me. I cannot let my therapist see my struggle. My journey is a reflection of my therapist. My therapist will judge me and abandon me if I am honest. I have made no progress to be proud of. How others feel about me and themselves is my responsibility.

174.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
174.Input.client_statement: [Angry] My doctor said I have to come see you about my “anger problem.” Sometimes when I get really angry, I lose control and hit people. I just get so angry when people say stupid things! Are you sure that you will be able to help me with this?
174.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Explain the logic of how CBT can be used to address concerns
174.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Instill hope for using CBT effectively
174.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Set appropriate expectations for the nature and impact of CBT
174.Input.exe: Exercise: Explaining the Treatment Rationale for Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
174.Input.res_a: I completely understand why you're feeling skeptical, and I appreciate your honesty about your concerns. Cognitive-behavioral therapy, or CBT, is a helpful approach that can assist you in managing your anger. By working together, we can identify patterns and triggers that contribute to your anger, and learn more adaptive ways to cope with those situations. This doesn't mean suppressing your emotions, but rather learning to manage them in a more constructive manner.
174.Input.res_b: It sounds like you’re angry now. Let’s talk about your concerns about whether you are going to get the help you want. We can put that on our agenda for today. I’d also like to talk with you about how we can make a plan for if or when you feel angry in here. Could we talk about that today too? First, though, I’d like to get a better sense for the degree to which you think you have an anger problem?
174.ori_text: Hello, I have an issue with something a therapist calls ‘negative association’. When a negative event, for example-someone calls me ‘ugly’, I’ll feel bad about it. Then, I’ll think about the person who called me ‘ugly’ and associate their gender, with the event. I also do this when I’m at a place. If something bad happens at a certain place, if it’s a school or a store, I’ll avoid that place to not remember the event.
174.situation: When a negative event happens, I'll feel bad about it. Then, I'll think of the person/places that are associated with the negative event, I'll avoid that person or place.
174.thoughts:
- This woman (or man) said I was ugly, so I need to avoid all women.
- Something bad happened here, so this is a bad place.
- Only bad things happen to me in this place/with these kind of people.
- I need to avoid things that make me feel bad. 
- I feel bad, so that means it's true that this place/person is dangerous/bad.

175.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
175.Input.client_statement: [Angry] It’s hard to come up with goals because I’m not really sure what we’re doing in here.
175.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation
175.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the goals and tasks
175.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize concrete, actionable, and measurable goals
175.Input.res_a: It sounds like you’re feeling frustrated. Establishing goals can feel overwhelming, especially when the process seems unclear. Let’s work together to define what you hope to achieve. We can start small and build from there, ensuring each step aligns with your values and long-term aspirations.
175.Input.res_b: That’s important to hear, and I can see how that might make it hard to come up with goals! Just to clarify, is the uncertainty about therapy in general or the CBT model that we’ve started to introduce? It might seem a bit backward, but identifying potential goals can also inform what we do in here.
175.ori_text: Almost constantly; while I’m driving I think about getting into a crash, while I’m sitting at home I think about being robbed or killing myself. Anything, really. I want these things to happen and sometimes I gain the motivation to do something about it myself but I never really have the means or the motivation (for lack of a better word) wears off. To me, it doesn’t matter whether the fantasy ends with my dying or not, and whether it is preferred or not really varies. Recently I had a friend kill himself, and obviously it got to me; but this all started way before he hung himself. While I am devastated about his loss, I also feel an odd sense of guilt and envy because he actually did what I’ve always wanted to/thought about doing.
175.situation: This client is experiencing intrusive thoughts about death and dying.
175.thoughts: I don't care if I live, other people don't care if I live, my life doesn't matter, I don't have what it takes to end my own life - I can't even do that right, my life is worthless, I am worthless, there is no hope for me, there is no way out of this feeling.

176.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
176.Input.client_statement: [Frustrated] My boss’s evaluation of me was devastating. I’m at a loss. There is no other perspective on this.
176.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
176.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
176.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
176.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
176.Input.res_a: It sounds like you might be feeling helpless. If I was convinced that my boss’s evaluation of me was devastating, I might feel helpless too. Maybe we can see if there is or is not another perspective on this? Let’s explore what happened in more detail.
176.Input.res_b: It sounds like this evaluation has really shaken you up. Let's break it down together. Can you help me identify any thoughts that might be contributing to your feeling of being "at a loss"? What are some negative or unhelpful thoughts that come up for you when you think about your boss's evaluation?
176.ori_text: I read a question that was similar to the one I have, but I did not believe it could fully be used for my situation. Both my girlfriend and me are 20 years of age. We have been together since July 2nd 2010, and it is March 28th 2011. We were friends for many years before we started dating but due to both of us moving around we were not able to have a relationship. She is everything I ever wanted in a woman and I am so happy to have her in my life. I had no sexual interactions what so ever before I was with her, she is my first in everything. Unfortunately, I am not her first in many things, if anything at all, and that is very hurtful and distressing to me. When she was growing up her parents neglected and even abused her. She was molested on several occasions, but never by a family member. Her life has not been one of happiness and is full of past pains that plague her to this day. She never felt loved or cared about by anyone, and sought out relationships to fill this void. Her first sexual experience was with a female, they were friends and one night during a sleep over her friend put her hand down my girlfriends pants and began feeling around down there. My girlfriend said she did it back to her friend. She was bisexual for a while and dated a few girls, but never did anything for that kiss them. Though not often she claims. Her first sexual experience with a boyfriend was when she was 14 and the guy she was dating asked her to touch him, and so she did. She says she didn’t want to but did it to make him happy. In her next relationship she let him suck on her breasts and finger her, she touched him but while he had pants on so there was no contact with his penis. In her third relationship she also let him finger her and she gave him a hand job as well. In her last relationship she went out with this guy for 2.5 years and she really loved him. He was the first she gave oral sex to, and they did everything together. He fingered her; she gave him many hand jobs and lots of oral sex. She wanted to have sex and so did he, but she brought it up to him. They agreed and she claims that he only penetrated her a little bit before finishing, so she doesn’t believe she lost her virginity. He claims that every time they tried, which both him and her say was 3 times, that they had full intercourse but she swears that after that first time having failed, and the other two times they never got past being naked, none of the times they ever had full intercourse. I don’t know if she’s trying to protect me because she knows how bad it would hurt me if they actually did, or if she really didn’t have full on sex with him. I know her was able to penetrate her at least somewhat so I also have issues with whether she was still a virgin the first time we had sex.
176.situation: She is everything I ever wanted in a woman and I am so happy to have her in my life. Unfortunately, I am not her first in many things, if anything at all, and that is very hurtful and distressing to me.
176.thoughts: If I’m not her first, she won’t love me forever. She will leave me because I’m not special to her. She is everything to me. If she leaves me, I will be nothing. I won’t ever be able to find someone as amazing as she is. I think she’s lying to me about her virginity, which just means she is probably lying about her feelings for me, too, and it’s only a matter of time before she realizes it and leaves me.

177.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
177.Input.client_statement: [Angry] Honestly, I just don’t see how you can help me. I mean, sure, if I had your life maybe I could sit around and relax at the end of everyday too, but I don’t! In my life, I don’t get to relax. So, I just don’t see how you’re going to be able to fix that for me.
177.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
177.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Empathically explore the clientʼs experience of treatment and you
177.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Validate clientsʼ experience and “roll with” versus challenging their resistance
177.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Support clientsʼ autonomy and elicit their motivation for pursuing valued directions
177.Input.res_a: I’m so glad that you told me how you’ve been feeling. It sounds like I’m not understanding what it’s like to be you and that some of the suggestions that I’ve made have been off the mark for the demands that exist in your life. I can definitely see how that would be incredibly frustrating. I’d really like to understand your perspective better. I think that doing so will help us work together to come up with some things that will be more personally helpful for you. How does that sound?
177.Input.res_b: It sounds like you're feeling really frustrated and overwhelmed right now. It's completely understandable to feel that way. My role isn't to fix your life but to help you develop tools and strategies that can make a difference in how you handle stress and challenges. Let's explore together what specific aspects of your life are causing you the most stress and see if there are any small, manageable changes we can work on to help you feel more in control and relaxed.
177.ori_text: So much has happened in the last month I am not quite sure where to start, but here it is. Over the Christmas period my boyfriend was slightly distant, we live together but for Christmas day he went to his parents and I went to mine. He then came to my parents on Boxing day and although we all had a lovely day I noticed he was distant. Things seemed ok after that, however before Christmas he complained of an upset stomach and had not eaten much at all the week before Christmas. We put it down to a stomach bug as there seemed to be a lot going round but he was reluctant to go to the doctor. This ‘stomach bug’, however, then continued after Christmas.
177.situation: ...although we all had a lovely day I noticed he was distant...
177.thoughts: I am confused by this situation, I do not know how to interpret this or respond. I cannot trust myself. I cannot trust my own thoughts about this.

178.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
178.Input.client_statement: [Curious] I’m still trying to get the hang of identifying my thoughts. What should I plan for next week?
178.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
178.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
178.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
178.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
178.Input.res_a: Let's set a goal for you to keep a thought record for one week, writing down situations, thoughts, and emotions that arise. This will help you become more aware of your thoughts and identify patterns.
178.Input.res_b: Do keep in mind that this is something few of us do naturally. How about practicing thought records a bit more on your own, as I think this would be a good challenge? Shall we develop a practice plan?
178.ori_text: I grew up bouncing from house to house. Sometimes with my mom, but most of the time with grandparents or having my sister look after me. My father left when I was 2 and popped his head in here and there. He and my mother are both addicts. My mother got clean when I was 15, but is still an alcoholic. Because of their addictions, I never really had a real home, let alone parents. I was never able to count on them and they were constantly letting me down. When was 17 and graduated high school I left for college and never looked back. I knew I needed to make something of myself so that I would not turn into them.
178.situation: I was never able to count on them and they were constantly letting me down.
178.thoughts: I cannot forgive my parents for what they put me through. I have problems trusting people because of my experiences. I would rather be alone than depend on others who may let me down or abandon me. My needs did not matter to my parents.

179.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
179.Input.client_statement: [Nervous] My partner wants us to talk about something today.
179.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
179.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
179.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
179.Input.res_a: OK. I’d like to hear more about that, and, most important, if this is something that you want us to put on the agenda today. Perhaps we can visit that after we review what you’ve been working on over the past week?
179.Input.res_b: It sounds like you're feeling a bit apprehensive about discussing something with your partner. Can you tell me a bit more about what you're expecting to talk about and what's making you feel nervous about it?
179.ori_text: I’ve been depressed for a while, but I was always too embarrassed to get help. But now that I’ve ruined another relationship recently, I decided I should seek help. As a young child, I was always put down by my brother and felt I was never good enough because my dad would never congratulate me on anything, just that I can do better. Now that I’ve been trying to have a relationship with girls, I always make them hate me by putting myself down. Everything I do just makes me feel worse about myself, and I need help with my confidence before I end up hurting myself.
179.situation: Now that I’ve been trying to have a relationship with girls, I always make them hate me by putting myself down.
179.thoughts:
- It's my fault that my relationships fail.
- It's embarrassing and shameful that I need help.
- I am a loser and I can't do anything right.
- My emotions are out of control.
- I don't deserve a loving relationship.
- My girlfriends were probably going to leave me anyway, because I'm not worth their love.
- I don't deserve to be happy.

180.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
180.Input.client_statement: [Angry] You just need goals to write down for the insurance companies so you get paid for this.
180.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation
180.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the goals and tasks
180.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize concrete, actionable, and measurable goals
180.Input.res_a: I understand that you feel this way, and it's important to address those concerns. Goals are actually a collaborative process designed to help you make tangible, positive changes in your life. Let's discuss what you hope to achieve, so we can ensure the goals are meaningful and aligned with your personal growth. Your progress and satisfaction are the priority here.
180.Input.res_b: OK, so if I’m understanding you, you’re suggesting that I’m asking to set goals for reasons other than that they’ll be helpful to you. Is that right? It seems like you’re concerned about me being really committed to you. You deserve to feel confident your therapist is really concerned about you, not just getting paid, so let’s put this on the agenda and talk about it. Would that be OK?
180.ori_text: I believe that I have issues trusting people. I grew up in a home where my parents hated each other and it was no secret. I never liked my mother who is controlling and selfish. My mother wouldn’t accept anything unless in her mind it was right. My father, for half of my life, was an alcoholic and didn’t come home very often. Although when my father was at home I would spend all of my time with him. At one point in my life my parents separated and my father disappeared without notice or any phone number we could even reach him at. I was devastated. The relationship between my mother and me only got worse. We would constantly get into fights and physical altercations just because I viewed something differently than her. Eventually my father stopped drinking and my parents thought they would give their marriage and our family a second chance. Nothing ever changed; except for the fact my father was sober.
180.situation: I grew up in a home where my parents hated each other and it was no secret. My parents separated and my father disappeared with no notice, and the relationship between my mother and me only got worse. Eventually my father stopped drinking and my parents got back together but nothing ever changed.
180.thoughts:
- I am the problem.
- Nobody loves me.
- I am trapped in this situation.
- My parents are out to get me.
- Nothing will ever change.

181.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
181.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I’m not ready to try the next item on my exposure hierarchy.
181.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and transparent stance
181.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Demonstrate openness to explore before determining if a modification is indeed warranted
181.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain consistency with a broad CBT orientation
181.Input.res_a: Let's break it down together. It sounds like you're feeling anxious about moving forward with the next step in your exposure hierarchy. What are some thoughts that are contributing to this anxiety, and what's holding you back from feeling ready to proceed?
181.Input.res_b: OK. As we discussed, the plan is not completely encased in stone. Before we consider an adjustment, can we explore what might be concerning you about this?
181.ori_text: About a year ago I re-entered into a serious relationship with an ex-boyfriend. He is essentially my only ‘real’ ex. We were together through both of our college careers and were only apart for one year before we got back together. For the most part I think we have a very healthy and positive relationship. We are kind and supportive to each other. We communicate about everything and of course we care for each other a great deal. In all the time we’ve been together neither of us has ever cheated on the other, but for some reason I find myself constantly paranoid that he will. I’m sure this is a common problem, but as I looked through similar questions that had already been asked, it seemed that most of the inquisitors had obvious past issues that would give them inevitable trust issues; a father who left, a spouse who had cheated in the past, etc. I, however, do not have a sorted past whatsoever. I have to two loving supportive parents who are still together, I was never abused as a child, I’ve had my share of heartbreak but it all came before college and nothing was too traumatic.
181.situation: I, however, do not have a sorted past whatsoever. I have to two loving supportive parents who are still together, I was never abused as a child, I’ve had my share of heartbreak but it all came before college and nothing was too traumatic.
181.thoughts: There is something wrong with me. I have to figure out why I'm constantly worried my boyfriend will cheat. I cannot figure this out and it's bothering me. I don't fit the profile of someone who typically has these types of fears. I cannot trust my gut. I cannot trust myself. I must be wrong to fear this happening. I should not be having these fears. There is no reason for these fears.

182.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
182.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation
182.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the goals and tasks
182.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize concrete, actionable, and measurable goals
182.Input.res_a: The length of therapy can vary depending on several factors, such as the complexity of the issues and your level of engagement. Generally, CBT is a short-term approach, and we can expect to see significant progress within 6-12 sessions. However, we'll work together to set specific, achievable goals and regularly assess our progress to ensure we're on track.
182.Input.res_b: That’s an important question, and the answer is, it depends, in part based on your goals and preferences. I can say that this therapy will not be indefinite because we’ll work to give you the skills to become your own therapist and carry forward the work independently. Tell me more about your question. Are you worried about being here forever?
182.ori_text: I have a 23 years old sister and her behaviors cause anxiety. We moved to Canada about 2 years ago and since then I feel responsible a lot about her. Our parents are in back home and I feel I have to protect her and do as much as I can for her. She imputes to me all the tasks she has to do. She doesn’t eat at all in a day or she eats fast food (she is overweight), she doesn’t sleep in normal ours, she is depressed and doesn’t have friends at all. I can’t stop thinking about something will happen to her so bad bc she doesn’t eat. Sometimes I think she will get a big health problem or mental issue and I am trying to think about how can I deal with it. I try to help her and talk to her often about what she should eat or she should go to nutritionist or psychologist but she never listen to me and she says I don’t know why I am like this, I want to change my behaviors but I can’t. I just want to stop worrying, I feel sick. I can’t live my life if I can’t stop worrying about her all the time. (From Canada)
182.situation: This client is struggling with feeling responsible for their sister's mental health and overall well-being.
182.thoughts: If I don't help my sister something bad might happen to her, If something bad happens to my sister it will be all my fault, I am responsible for my sister's well-being, I can't help my sister, I can't live my own life.

183.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
183.Input.client_statement: [Dismissive] I’m not sure this is the right thing for me.
183.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Explain the logic of how CBT can be used to address concerns
183.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Instill hope for using CBT effectively
183.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Set appropriate expectations for the nature and impact of CBT
183.Input.exe: Exercise: Explaining the Treatment Rationale for Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
183.Input.res_a: I completely understand your reservations. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) may seem unfamiliar, but I'd like to explain how it can help. CBT is a problem-focused approach that helps you identify and change negative thought patterns and behaviors that contribute to your distress. By understanding how your thoughts, feelings, and actions interact, we can work together to develop more constructive ways of thinking and coping. Would you like me to elaborate on how this process works?
183.Input.res_b: I think that’s really important to acknowledge. I’d like to better understand what’s behind your concerns. I can say it’s pretty common for people to be uncertain about whether therapy is the right option for them, whether therapy in general or of a particular type. Based on what I’ve heard thus far, I believe that therapy could help you, but I want to help you make an informed choice that is going to best meet your needs at this time.
183.ori_text: I have been with my partner for over 3 years. In previous relationships I have been cheated on and I’m bringing my insecurities into my present relationship. He has never done anything to hurt me or given me any reason to doubt him yet I always think he wants more or would be happier without me. I recently checked his email, which was wrong, but I now don’t know if he’ll ever forgive me for it. Although I found out he had been flirting with a women and he claims I would have done the same it doesn’t mean anything. I don’t want to cause problems in the relationship but I don’t know how I can get over my stupidity of being so insecure.
183.situation: He has never done anything to hurt me or given me any reason to doubt him yet I always think he wants more or would be happier without me...Although I found out he had been flirting with a women and he claims I would have done the same it doesn’t mean anything. I don’t want to cause problems in the relationship but I don’t know how I can get over my stupidity of being so insecure.
183.thoughts: My feelings of insecurity and worry are invalid and wrong. I should feel ashamed of feeling worried and insecure in this relationship. If I feel worried or insecure, it is only my fault. I cannot trust my gut. I cannot trust myself. I must accept love in any way it comes. I must accept him flirting with other women. I must believe him that I would do the same. I must believe him that it doesn't mean anything. If he says something, it must be true and I must be wrong. If there is a problem in our relationship then it is my fault. I cannot cause problems in this relationship because then he may leave me, and I cannot be alone.

184.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
184.Input.client_statement: [Disgusted, looking away] Ugh. Ahh. That is disgusting! I am not looking at that or touching it!
184.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Empathically inquire about clientsʼ emotional experience
184.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Actively listen and maintain a supportive tone to clientsʼ emotional disclosures
184.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Model tolerance of affect and an approach orientation to clientsʼ strong emotional experience
184.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Use psychoeducation to support the importance of clients experiencing versus avoiding their emotion and the maladaptive consequences of negative reinforcement
184.Input.res_a: Let's take a step back and explore what's happening here. What is it about this situation that's triggering such a strong reaction of disgust? Can you help me understand what's going through your mind right now?
184.Input.res_b: We shouldn’t pretend it isn’t disgusting. But you’ve been through so much, dealing with this. Try to think about the things that are dear to you, what kind of life you want to live. This is where you turn the corner.

185.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
185.Input.client_statement: [Nervous] I know that the plan was to talk about exposure today, but something’s come up that I’d like to talk about first.
185.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
185.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
185.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
185.Input.res_a: It's completely okay to adjust our agenda if something urgent has come up. Your concerns are important, and we can definitely address what's on your mind right now. Let's take some time to discuss the new issue, and if time permits, we can also touch upon exposure therapy. How does that sound to you?
185.Input.res_b: So, here’s my thought. My experience is that exposure can be scary and challenging, and I’ve found if we get started on the road of putting it off because something else came up, then it becomes easier and easier to keep putting off. Then we find ourselves off our agreed-on path. So, my suggestion would be let’s do some exposure first and aim to save some time for the other topic. Does that plan work for you?

186.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
186.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I’m not sure I’m ready to do this on my own.
186.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Provide a basic rationale for the homework assignment
186.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Tailor the homework assignment to the clientʼs concerns and needs
186.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Ensure that there is adequate agreement on and understanding of the homework assignment
186.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Encourage and validate good-faith efforts
186.Input.exe: Exercise: Assigning and Reviewing Between-Session Activities
186.Input.res_a: I totally get it. This is new and far from easy, so I’m not surprised that you’re unsure. If this was a “slam dunk,” we probably wouldn’t spend too much of your time on it. On the one hand, we want to push beyond your comfort zone a bit, but on the other hand, we also don’t want to blow right past it if that isn’t going to be helpful. Let’s take a moment to discuss some of your concerns and come up with a plan that seems workable. I would especially like to discuss what you would most like to work on before next session.
186.Input.res_b: It's completely normal to feel uncertain about taking on new challenges independently. Let's take a closer look at the between-session activities we've discussed. Which specific tasks are causing you the most concern? Are there any thoughts or doubts that are contributing to your anxiety about doing them on your own? By identifying and addressing these concerns, we can work together to break down the tasks into more manageable steps and develop a plan to help you feel more confident and prepared to tackle them outside of our sessions. How does that sound?

187.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
187.Input.client_statement: [Relieved] I’m glad you could see my reluctance about cognitive behavioral therapy! I think it started to feel more like a class than a treatment, which was unhelpful. I do want to work on feeling better—and thinking better [laughs]—but sometimes I don’t have a clear agenda or direction. In those times, just taking some space to talk freely helps me a lot.
187.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
187.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Empathically explore the clientʼs experience of treatment and you
187.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Validate clientsʼ experience and “roll with” versus challenging their resistance
187.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Support clientsʼ autonomy and elicit their motivation for pursuing valued directions
187.Input.res_a: I'm glad we could have this conversation, and I appreciate your honesty about feeling like the therapy sessions were becoming too structured for you. It's completely normal to feel that way, and I'm happy to adjust our approach to better suit your needs. In fact, taking space to talk freely is a valuable part of our therapy, and I'm open to incorporating more of that into our sessions. Can we explore what specifically makes you feel like you need more space to talk freely?
187.Input.res_b: I’m glad I asked too. I just sensed that we were not well aligned, and I’m so glad I understand why. We can absolutely balance the structured and unstructured activities, as I too would prefer not to fall into a “lesson” mode. So, how would you like to proceed now, in this moment? I want to meet you where it’s most useful, and please let me know whenever that’s not occurring, in case I miss it.

188.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
188.Input.client_statement: [Frustrated] My boss’s evaluation of me was devastating. I’m at a loss. There is no other perspective on this.
188.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
188.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
188.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
188.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
188.Input.res_a: It sounds like you might be feeling helpless. If I was convinced that my boss’s evaluation of me was devastating, I might feel helpless too. Maybe we can see if there is or is not another perspective on this? Let’s explore what happened in more detail.
188.Input.res_b: I understand that the evaluation was upsetting. However, let's explore the idea that there's no other perspective. Is it possible that your boss's feedback, although negative, might be an opportunity for growth and learning? Can we examine some alternative viewpoints together?

189.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
189.Input.client_statement: [Pessimistic] I know I agreed to this approach, and I understand what we’re trying to do here, but I’m starting to doubt it’s a good fit.
189.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
189.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Empathically explore the clientʼs experience of treatment and you
189.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Validate clientsʼ experience and “roll with” versus challenging their resistance
189.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Support clientsʼ autonomy and elicit their motivation for pursuing valued directions
189.Input.res_a: It's completely normal to have doubts, especially when trying something new. Can you tell me more about what's causing you to question our approach? Is it a specific aspect that's not resonating with you or something else?
189.Input.res_b: I’m so glad you told me this, as your outlook on therapy is central to it working. Let’s shift gears for a moment, put aside our agenda, and just discuss what has or has not felt like a fit for you. How does that sound?

190.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
190.Input.client_statement: [Frustrated] I know I said I would go to the event and start a conversation with new people, but I only managed to say “hello” to one person.
190.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and transparent stance
190.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Demonstrate openness to explore before determining if a modification is indeed warranted
190.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain consistency with a broad CBT orientation
190.Input.res_a: It seems like you might be a bit disappointed by this, but I see this as significant progress. It was a big accomplishment to show up to the event in the first place and then say hello to someone you don’t know. Let’s talk about what that was like.
190.Input.res_b: It sounds like you're feeling frustrated, but it's important to recognize the small steps you have taken. Saying "hello" to even one person is progress. Let's explore what made that challenging and how we can build on this experience for next time.

191.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
191.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I know I sometimes think in extremes, but what if the worst thing actually did happen? It could.
191.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
191.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
191.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
191.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
191.Input.res_a: I hear you. Sometimes our biggest fears or concerns do rear their ugly head. Can you give me an example of a “worst thing”? Let’s say it did occur, what’s the absolute worst effect on you? Any sense of how you might cope?
191.Input.res_b: You're acknowledging that your thoughts can be quite extreme, which is a great first step. Let's explore this idea of the "worst-case scenario." Can you think of a specific situation where you've had this thought, and what was the outcome?

192.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
192.Input.client_statement: [Nervous] I have a hard time with organization, so I’m worried about doing all of the homework correctly.
192.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Explain the logic of how CBT can be used to address concerns
192.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Instill hope for using CBT effectively
192.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Set appropriate expectations for the nature and impact of CBT
192.Input.exe: Exercise: Explaining the Treatment Rationale for Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
192.Input.res_a: I understand your concern and would like, first, to clarify the exact nature of it. In general, before we send you out the door with an assignment, we’ll spend some time thinking about what might make it hard for you to do and figure out a strategy or two to help with that. How does that sound?
192.Input.res_b: It's completely normal to feel nervous about taking on new tasks, especially when they involve organizing and structure. That's why we'll work together to break down the homework assignments into smaller, manageable steps, making it easier to tackle each task at a time. This will help you build confidence and develop a sense of control over your organization skills.

193.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
193.Input.client_statement: [Panicking] After touching all of the bathroom walls with millions of germs—I am going to wash my hands immediately! I get the point of exposure, but it’s crazy not to wash your hands after what we just did.
193.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and curious stance
193.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Be clear when suggesting a plan of action and expectations
193.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Be positive and supportive of both big and small positive changes
193.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Appeal to relevant core learning concepts, including conditioning, reinforcement, the importance of environment, antecedents, and consequences
193.Input.res_a: I understand your concern about germs, but let's examine the thought pattern here. Are you assuming that touching the walls guarantees illness? Is it possible that your body can handle some exposure to germs without getting sick? Let's weigh the pros and cons of washing your hands immediately versus waiting a bit longer as part of our exposure exercise.
193.Input.res_b: I hear you. Recall that there are two parts to this work—the actual exposure and then preventing the behaviors that you typically engage in to respond to the perceived threat of the germs. We need to fully disrupt this process of negative reinforcement if you are going to overcome this problem; in other words, refraining from washing is also critical.

194.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
194.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] Whenever I have trouble motivating to do the homework, I think of how happy I will feel telling you that I did it. Your approval means everything to me. I honestly think you’re the best therapist I’ve ever met.
194.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Provide a basic rationale for the homework assignment
194.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Tailor the homework assignment to the clientʼs concerns and needs
194.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Ensure that there is adequate agreement on and understanding of the homework assignment
194.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Encourage and validate good-faith efforts
194.Input.exe: Exercise: Assigning and Reviewing Between-Session Activities
194.Input.res_a: Thank you for sharing that with me. It's great that thinking of our sessions motivates you to complete the homework. However, I want to explore this idea of seeking my approval. What would happen if you didn't receive my approval or validation? Would you still feel motivated to work on your goals?
194.Input.res_b: I’m glad to hear how much you’re invested in this work and that you can find ways to stay motivated to continue the work between sessions, which can be difficult. I wonder if there are other potential sources of motivation. If we take me out of the equation, what would be most useful and meaningful to you?

195.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
195.Input.client_statement: [Agitated] Wow. You won’t believe what happened this week. It’s a really long story . . .
195.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
195.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
195.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
195.Input.res_a: I'm glad you feel comfortable sharing this with me. I'm here to listen and help you work through it. Before we dive into the details, can we take a moment to set a clear direction for our session today? What are the most important issues or topics you'd like to focus on during our time together? This will help us stay on track and ensure we make the most of our session.
195.Input.res_b: It sounds like there’s a lot on your mind, and I’d like to hear about it. Would it be OK to take a second to discuss our agenda for the day first, including where discussing this past week might fit in, as well as anything else you want to take up here today? I want to make sure that we budget our time accordingly. Shall we start with a homework check-in and then tackle the story?

196.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
196.Input.client_statement: [Frustrated] I don’t like it when you ask me if I have “catastrophic thoughts.” Aren’t catastrophes reserved for wars and natural disasters? So, no, I don’t think I catastrophize. Please don’t ask again.
196.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
196.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Empathically explore the clientʼs experience of treatment and you
196.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Validate clientsʼ experience and “roll with” versus challenging their resistance
196.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Support clientsʼ autonomy and elicit their motivation for pursuing valued directions
196.Input.res_a: It seems like my words upset you, and I totally get it. Here I am using a CBT term that I assumed would be relevant you, when in fact it’s not. I really should not have made that assumption, and I’ll do better to check in. In fact, I wonder if you find any part of focusing on your cognitions to be useful?
196.Input.res_b: I understand your frustration. The term 'catastrophic thoughts' can be misleading. In CBT, it refers to a pattern of thinking where we assume the worst-case scenario, even if it's unlikely. I'm not suggesting your thoughts are equivalent to wars or natural disasters. Can we explore how you think about challenging situations and see if we can identify any patterns that might be contributing to your distress?

197.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
197.Input.client_statement: [Irritated] When we work through these thought records, it’s not hard to come up with alternative evidence and thoughts, but it feels artificial and doesn’t really make me feel better.
197.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
197.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
197.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
197.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
197.Input.res_a: I understand your concerns about the process feeling artificial. That's a common experience, especially when we're just starting out with cognitive restructuring. It's almost as if we're trying on a new pair of shoes that don't quite fit yet. It's helpful to remember that the goal of this exercise isn't to simply replace one thought with another, but rather to learn to examine and challenge our thoughts in a more balanced way. With time and practice, this process can become more natural and lead to changes in how you feel. Can you think of a time when you did something that felt awkward at first, but eventually became second nature?
197.Input.res_b: This is helpful, what you’re telling me. I suggest we take a look at this thought record we just worked through and see if we can understand more about why it’s not helping you. It sounds like the practice of identifying alternatives feels disingenuous compared to your typical automatic thoughts. We could start by asking for each of the alternative thoughts, “How much do you actually believe this thought?” We can also take a look to see if there are any action plans you can make for things you can do that might help you feel better about this situation. Or maybe we just need to bail out of thought records. Maybe they are not the right tool for you.

198.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
198.Input.client_statement: [Hopeless] Before being diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, I loved hiking. I’m devastated because nothing is going to replace that. It’s all over.
198.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and curious stance
198.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Be clear when suggesting a plan of action and expectations
198.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Be positive and supportive of both big and small positive changes
198.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Appeal to relevant core learning concepts, including conditioning, reinforcement, the importance of environment, antecedents, and consequences
198.Input.res_a: I can see why you'd feel that way, given how much hiking meant to you. However, let's not jump to conclusions just yet. While it's true that multiple sclerosis may limit some physical activities, it doesn't necessarily mean you'll never find another fulfilling hobby or interest. Can you think of any aspects of hiking that you enjoyed, such as being outdoors or exploring nature? Maybe we can explore alternative activities that still allow you to engage with those aspects.
198.Input.res_b: I hear that it’s frustrating. And at some level you’re right; nothing else is going to perfectly “replace” what you used to do. It’s possible this expectation makes it hard to take the first step toward finding new, meaningful activities. Perhaps we can brainstorm some concrete options that would still be of interest, without any particular expectations that they would be, at least immediately, as enjoyable or meaningful as hiking?

199.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
199.Input.client_statement: [Confused] I’m not sure I want to do homework or exercises in here.
199.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation
