199.Input.res_a: As we’ve discussed, the CBT approach tends to emphasize learning by doing—in particular, trying things out in between sessions, in your daily life. Although each person is different, it can be difficult to translate or generalize the work we do in here to your day-to-day life without trying out new things and applying them outside of here. Now, that can look a lot of different ways, depending on your preferences and the given week. Perhaps we can discuss some of your concerns and expectations regarding homework?
199.Input.res_b: It's understandable to feel unsure about the idea of homework or exercises in therapy. In CBT, these tasks are designed to help you become more aware of your thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, and to learn new skills that can help you manage challenges in your life. They can be a bit uncomfortable at first, but they can also be a powerful tool in helping you achieve your goals. Can you tell me more about what's making you hesitant about doing these exercises?

200.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice

What about brainstorming what part or parts of this might be more feasible over the next week? I would suggest that we not abandon this completely because doing at least some homework has been shown to relate to improvement. But you can only do what you can fit in. So, again, let’s think in terms of part or parts. Thoughts?

Even dedicating just a few minutes daily can be beneficial. We can also adjust the activities to ensure they feel more doable. It’s about finding what works best for you, and your well-being is our priority. How does that sound?

201.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
201.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I don’t think I want to do any exposure.
201.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation

How did it make you feel, and how do you think it contributes to your goals? Let's explore how this positive experience might help reinforce some of the strategies we've been working on, and how you can use this excitement to maintain flexibility in your thinking and behaviors.

203.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
203.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I’m not sure I’m ready to do this on my own.
203.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Provide a basic rationale for the homework assignment

On the one hand, we want to push beyond your comfort zone a bit, but on the other hand, we also don’t want to blow right past it if that isn’t going to be helpful. Let’s take a moment to discuss some of your concerns and come up with a plan that seems workable. I would especially like to discuss what you would most like to work on before next session.

I want to assure you that I'll be here to support you every step of the way. Between our sessions, I encourage you to try out the exercises and activities we've assigned, but don't worry if you don't get it perfect - it's all about progress, not perfection. We can review and adjust as needed in our next session. How about we make a plan together for how you can start with one small step, and I'll check in with you next time to see how it's going?

229.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice

229.Input.res_a: It's completely normal to feel anxious about trying something new on your own. However, between-session activities are designed to help reinforce what we've discussed and give you practical experience in a supportive way. Let's start with something manageable and set clear, achievable goals together. We can review your progress in our next session and adjust as needed. Remember, the purpose is not to get it perfect but to learn and grow through the process. How does starting with a small, specific task sound to you? We’re in this together, and I’m here to support you every step of the way.
229.Input.res_b: I totally get it. This is new and far from easy, so I’m not surprised that you’re unsure. If this was a “slam dunk,” we probably wouldn’t spend too much of your time on it. On the one hand, we want to push beyond your comfort zone a bit, but on the other hand, we also don’t want to blow right past it if that isn’t going to be helpful. Let’s take a moment to discuss some of your concerns and come up with a plan that seems workable. I would especially like to discuss what you would most like to work on before next session.

232.Input.res_a: We want to help you focus on your thoughts in a new way, almost like a detective building a case for how true or untrue they are. We don’t want you to just spend more time feeling bad or focusing on painful thoughts; rather, there are different ways to monitor your thoughts that can provide helpful information that you may typically overlook. Such reflection might help you see things more complexly, or from different angles, which can also help you experience things differently. Does that make sense?
232.Input.res_b: I understand your concern. Focusing on negative thoughts might seem counterintuitive at first. However, identifying and understanding these thoughts can help us uncover patterns and distorted thinking. By addressing these directly, we can challenge and reframe them into more balanced, realistic perspectives. Over time, this approach can reduce their power over your emotions and behavior, leading to a more positive mindset and overall sense of well-being. It's about gaining control rather than letting those thoughts control you.

Can we examine the thought that it might be easier for everyone if you were dead?

Cognitive-behavioral therapy can help you learn to manage these thoughts and feelings in a healthier way. By identifying and challenging negative thought patterns, we can work together to develop more balanced and constructive coping strategies, allowing you to break free from the cycle of depression and find more hope and resilience.

251.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice

251.Input.res_a: Yes, I totally get it. And, like we discussed, avoiding it brings temporary relief. But, often at a longer term cost. By avoiding something to feel relief, it’s like we tell ourselves that “this is too big and powerful for me to deal with in any other way,” which only strengthens the narrative and the emotion, giving it more control over you. Does that make sense? Do you remain motivated to see that we can lessen such power, even if it means tolerating discomfort to get there?

In CBT, we often work with the idea that avoidance can be a coping mechanism, but it might not be addressing the root of the issue. Can you tell me more about what you're avoiding and what emotions you typically experience when you're in that situation?

253.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice

Rather, we want to help you experience your feelings in new ways. This will help you reflect on them more objectively and respond to them in a more adaptive way to get your needs met and live the type of life that you want to live.

By exploring and challenging negative thought patterns and behaviors, we can learn to respond to situations in a more adaptive way. In CBT, we work together to identify and challenge unhelpful thoughts and replace them with more balanced and realistic ones, which can help you feel better and behave in more constructive ways.

Can you think of a recent situation where you felt like you just reacted without thinking? Let's break it down together and see if we can identify any patterns or thoughts that might have been present.

257.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice

Let’s explore what specific aspects feel artificial to you so we can tailor the approach to better suit your needs. Additionally, we'll look at other strategies within CBT that might resonate more with you and support your emotional well-being.
257.Input.res_b: This is helpful, what you’re telling me. I suggest we take a look at this thought record we just worked through and see if we can understand more about why it’s not helping you. It sounds like the practice of identifying alternatives feels disingenuous compared to your typical automatic thoughts. We could start by asking for each of the alternative thoughts, “How much do you actually believe this thought?” We can also take a look to see if there are any action plans you can make for things you can do that might help you feel better about this situation. Or maybe we just need to bail out of thought records. Maybe they are not the right tool for you.

273.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice

However, the goal of CBT is not to dwell on the negative, but to understand how these thoughts and feelings are influencing your behaviors and emotions. By becoming more aware of your negative thoughts, we can challenge and reframe them in a more balanced and realistic way, which can lead to a reduction in distress and improvement in overall well-being.

Such reflection might help you see things more complexly, or from different angles, which can also help you experience things differently. Does that make sense?

294.Input.res_b: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, or CBT, is a highly effective approach for individuals struggling with a wide range of issues, including anxiety, depression, and trauma. This treatment is helpful for people like you because it focuses on identifying and changing negative thought patterns and behaviors that contribute to distress. By learning new skills and strategies, you can develop a more balanced and adaptive way of thinking, leading to improved emotional regulation and overall well-being.

I’ll be alone forever”; and emotions of pain, grief, loss, hopelessness, helplessness. . . . OK, so now here is the question I have for you. Let’s focus on these emotions. 302.Input.res_a: I imagine that feels pretty overwhelming. Sometimes you think it would be easier for everyone if you were dead. Can we examine the thought that it might be easier for everyone if you were dead?
302.Input.res_b: I'm really sorry you're feeling this way. In Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, we work together to identify and reshape the negative thought patterns and behaviors that are contributing to your distress. By understanding how your thoughts, feelings, and actions are interconnected, you can develop healthier coping mechanisms and start to feel better over time. You're not alone in this, and there is hope for improvement.

303.Input.res_a: It's understandable to feel that way; worry can sometimes feel like it keeps us motivated. However, it's important to find a balance. Reducing excessive worry doesn't mean eliminating all concerns, but managing them in a healthier way. Let’s work together to differentiate between productive and unproductive worry, ensuring you stay accountable without overwhelming stress.

On the one hand, a lot of worrying stinks, but, on the other, it can also serve a purpose. That seems to put you in a bind, and maybe we’ve been ignoring the side of you that sort of values your worrying. Does that fit your experience?

314.Input.res_b: It sounds challenging. Let's identify specific triggers leading to missed or late appointments. Together, we can develop strategies, like setting reminders or creating a consistent routine, to help you manage your time effectively and reduce frustration.

315.Input.res_a: OK. I have a tentative agenda for today’s session based on how we have initially framed your concerns. What if we start by reviewing that and getting your input? We might also start by reviewing the homework, seeing if that suggests any other agenda items. How does that sound?

Is that something you'd like to revisit, or is there something else that's been occupying your thoughts and feelings that you'd like to discuss today?

We can spend a few minutes reviewing what you’ve worked on since the last session, and then we can discuss what is going to be most helpful between today and our next appointment— for example, continuing on with a similar plan or making some adjustments.

317.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice

Then we can brainstorm some methods to help with this, such as setting up reminders in the places you are least likely to miss them. How does this sound?
317.Input.res_b: Let's break this down. What are some specific thoughts that run through your mind when you're getting ready for an appointment? Are there any patterns or distractions that might be contributing to your tardiness or missed appointments?

318.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
318.Input.client_statement: [Concerned] I really need to know why I am the way I am now. I think understanding my past and childhood is really important, but it sounds like this approach doesn’t get into any of that?
318.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Explain the logic of how CBT can be used to address concerns
318.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Instill hope for using CBT effectively
318.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Set appropriate expectations for the nature and impact of CBT
318.Input.exe: Exercise: Explaining the Treatment Rationale for Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
318.Input.res_a: This is an important point of clarification. I actually agree that the past is important, and past experience is still relevant to this approach. Although we tend to focus on the present and what is going on now, your past is by no means “off limits.” In fact, we will probably need to discuss your past experiences to better understand your present life. If and when that seems most relevant, we will go there, while making sure that we connect things to what is most helpful for you now. Does that seem like a good fit for your interests?
318.Input.res_b: It's completely understandable to want to explore your past, as it can provide important context. While Cognitive Behavioral Therapy does focus on your current thoughts and behaviors, we don't ignore your history entirely. Instead, we look at how past experiences influence your current thought patterns. CBT is effective in helping you identify and change negative thinking and behavior patterns that may have developed over time. By understanding and modifying these patterns, you can improve how you feel and function now. We can certainly integrate aspects of your past when it's relevant to your current issues.

319.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
319.Input.client_statement: [Impatient] You talk about the importance of thoughts . . . I’m already very aware of my negative thoughts.
319.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs

319.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
319.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
319.Input.res_a: Being aware of your negative thoughts is a great first step, but in CBT, we also focus on understanding how those thoughts impact your emotions and behaviors. Let's explore how you respond to those thoughts. Do you try to challenge or modify them, or do you find yourself getting caught up in them, leading to feelings of frustration or hopelessness?
319.Input.res_b: You’re absolutely right that you live this every day and these thoughts are in your awareness. I was thinking that was actually a good thing, as it will help us as we work to find new ways of responding to them. But you sound unhappy about being so aware of your thoughts, so there is something else important here. Tell me more.

320.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
320.Input.client_statement: [Sad, failing to make eye contact] I guess I don’t deserve better.

320.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Be clear when suggesting a plan of action and expectations
320.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Be positive and supportive of both big and small positive changes
320.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Appeal to relevant core learning concepts, including conditioning, reinforcement, the importance of environment, antecedents, and consequences
320.Input.res_a: It sounds like you're having some negative self-talk about your worth, which can be really tough to deal with. Can you tell me more about what you mean by "deserve better" and what you think that means for you?
320.Input.res_b: I notice that when you say these things, it seems hard to even make eye contact with me. I think it would be important to understand how this behavior relates to your experience in here and outside of here.

321.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
321.Input.client_statement: [Angry] I don’t like this or find it helpful. My thoughts aren’t irrational or baseless, so I actually find it kind of invalidating and insulting.
321.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
321.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
321.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
321.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
321.Input.res_a: I appreciate you sharing this understandable feeling. It would be invalidating to have someone (including me) label your thoughts as irrational and baseless. To be sure, I’d like us both to assume that there is a way to understand the genuine bases of your thinking patterns, and how these are connected with other parts of your experience. Would you be open to exploring in more detail an example of when it felt like I was implying that your thoughts are invalid or baseless and work to find out what was contributing to that experience?
321.Input.res_b: I understand that you feel anger and frustration, and I respect your perspective. The goal of CBT isn’t to invalidate your thoughts but to explore them in a safe and supportive environment. It's about understanding how certain thought patterns might impact your emotions and behaviors. Would you be open to examining some of your thoughts together to see if we can identify any patterns or areas that might benefit from a different perspective? Your feelings and thoughts are always valid in our discussions.

322.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
322.Input.client_statement: [Angry] My partner cheated on me. And, no, there is no alternative explanation, so stop asking that! He cheated, so our relationship was a lie!
322.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda

322.Input.res_a: It's understandable to feel angry and betrayed. Let's explore how we can manage these intense emotions and figure out your next best steps together.
322.Input.res_b: I can feel that you’re very angry at me right now. My words must have hurt you; can you tell me more about this?

323.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
323.Input.client_statement: [Irritated] I can’t commit to coming in here each week. My schedule is unpredictable, and I don’t have a car.
323.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation

323.Input.res_a: That’s important to know. The evidence seems to show that more consistent, weekly sessions is best, on average. Can we discuss your concerns in more detail and brainstorm a plan to support your ability to make it to sessions, as well as how we’ll communicate about this as things come up?
323.Input.res_b: It sounds like you’re feeling frustrated with the current challenges. Let’s explore alternative options, like virtual sessions or bi-weekly meetings, to make therapy more accessible for you. What small, manageable steps could help integrate these sessions into your unpredictable schedule?

324.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
324.Input.client_statement: [Confused] I’m not sure I want to do homework or exercises in here.
324.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation

324.Input.res_a: It's completely normal to feel uncertain about doing homework or exercises at first. These activities are designed to help you outside of our sessions and provide you with practical tools to manage your feelings and challenges. Let's discuss what specific concerns or hesitations you have about doing them. Understanding your perspective can help us tailor the goals and exercises so they feel more manageable and personally meaningful to you. This way, we can ensure they're beneficial to your progress.
324.Input.res_b: As we’ve discussed, the CBT approach tends to emphasize learning by doing—in particular, trying things out in between sessions, in your daily life. Although each person is different, it can be difficult to translate or generalize the work we do in here to your day-to-day life without trying out new things and applying them outside of here. Now, that can look a lot of different ways, depending on your preferences and the given week. Perhaps we can discuss some of your concerns and expectations regarding homework?

325.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice

332.Input.res_a: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) does focus on understanding how your current thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are interconnected, but it doesn't necessarily delve into the past as deeply as other forms of therapy might. However, the goal of CBT isn't to ignore your past experiences, but rather to help you understand how they might be influencing your thoughts and behaviors in the present. By identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and learning new coping skills, you can break free from patterns that may be holding you back and move forward in a more positive direction.
332.Input.res_b: This is an important point of clarification. I actually agree that the past is important, and past experience is still relevant to this approach. If and when that seems most relevant, we will go there, while making sure that we connect things to what is most helpful for you now. Does that seem like a good fit for your interests?

351.Input.res_a: Now that we've created an exposure hierarchy, we'll work on assigning between-session activities to help you gradually face your fears and build confidence. This will involve identifying specific tasks to complete before our next session, making it more manageable and increasing your sense of control.
351.Input.res_b: The next step is to actually start working on the items on the hierarchy. I think you’re ready to try this on your own over the next week. Let’s start with the first item. Does that seem like something you could try next week?

352.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
352.Input.client_statement: [Nervous] What do we do next with this exposure thing?
352.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Provide a basic rationale for the homework assignment
352.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Tailor the homework assignment to the clientʼs concerns and needs
352.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Ensure that there is adequate agreement on and understanding of the homework assignment
352.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Encourage and validate good-faith efforts
352.Input.exe: Exercise: Assigning and Reviewing Between-Session Activities
352.Input.res_a: We’ve talked about how we want to translate or extend what we do in here to your life outside of here. If it works for you, I suggest we spend our remaining minutes thinking about and planning for the next week. Let’s find something on your hierarchy that you can aim for between today and our next session. It can be useful to have a few related options that slightly vary in expected difficulty. You might surprise yourself! Sound good?
352.Input.res_b: It's great that you're willing to engage in exposure exercises. Next, we'll identify specific situations or items causing you anxiety and create a hierarchy from least to most distressing. I'll guide you through gradual, manageable steps to confront these fears, starting with the least anxiety-provoking scenario. Between sessions, you'll practice these steps, keeping a journal of your experiences and feelings. We'll review your progress together, tweaking the plan as necessary for your comfort and success.

353.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
353.Input.client_statement: [Panicking] After touching all of the bathroom walls with millions of germs—I am going to wash my hands immediately! I get the point of exposure, but it’s crazy not to wash your hands after what we just did.
353.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and curious stance
353.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Be clear when suggesting a plan of action and expectations
353.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Be positive and supportive of both big and small positive changes
353.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Appeal to relevant core learning concepts, including conditioning, reinforcement, the importance of environment, antecedents, and consequences
353.Input.res_a: It's completely normal to feel anxious about exposure. Washing hands is habitual, but part of CBT involves gradually facing fears to lessen their power. Let's take a moment and observe what happens if you wait a bit before washing. Can we aim for a short delay, just a minute or two, to start?
353.Input.res_b: I hear you. Recall that there are two parts to this work—the actual exposure and then preventing the behaviors that you typically engage in to respond to the perceived threat of the germs. We need to fully disrupt this process of negative reinforcement if you are going to overcome this problem; in other words, refraining from washing is also critical.

354.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
354.Input.client_statement: [Nervous] I know that the plan was to talk about exposure today, but something’s come up that I’d like to talk about first.
354.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
354.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
354.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
354.Input.res_a: So, here’s my thought. My experience is that exposure can be scary and challenging, and I’ve found if we get started on the road of putting it off because something else came up, then it becomes easier and easier to keep putting off. Then we find ourselves off our agreed-on path. So, my suggestion would be let’s do some exposure first and aim to save some time for the other topic. Does that plan work for you?
354.Input.res_b: It takes a lot of courage to bring up something new, especially when we had a plan in place. Can you tell me a bit more about what's come up and why it feels important to discuss it today? I want to make sure we prioritize your needs, and we can always adjust the agenda accordingly. What's been going on that's got your attention, and how do you think it might relate to our work together?

355.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
355.Input.client_statement: [Happy] I did what you suggested about my thoughts, and it really helped in the moment. Every time I had a negative thought, I just told myself the opposite.
355.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
355.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
355.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
355.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
355.Input.res_a: That's a great start. It sounds like you've been practicing cognitive restructuring, which is a powerful tool in CBT. By challenging and reframing negative thoughts, you're taking control of your mental narrative. It's wonderful that you're experiencing some immediate benefits from this exercise. Now, I'd like to explore how you can integrate this skill into your daily life, making it a habit, and how you can apply it to more complex situations.
355.Input.res_b: It sounds like continued practice with identifying thoughts and coming up with alternative appraisals felt helpful, and I’m glad to hear that. I might reframe this work slightly, however. Considering the opposite can be a useful place to start, and we can also expand this to considering a number of alternative appraisals or interpretations that could enhance the flexibility of our thinking. Let’s actually take an example from this past week, shall we?

356.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
356.Input.client_statement: [Pessimistic] I know I agreed to this approach, and I understand what we’re trying to do here, but I’m starting to doubt it’s a good fit.
356.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
356.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Empathically explore the clientʼs experience of treatment and you
356.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Validate clientsʼ experience and “roll with” versus challenging their resistance
356.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Support clientsʼ autonomy and elicit their motivation for pursuing valued directions
356.Input.res_a: I understand that you're having some doubts about the approach, and that's completely normal. Let's explore these doubts together. What specifically is making you question whether CBT is a good fit for you?
356.Input.res_b: I’m so glad you told me this, as your outlook on therapy is central to it working. Let’s shift gears for a moment, put aside our agenda, and just discuss what has or has not felt like a fit for you. How does that sound?

357.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
357.Input.client_statement: [Hopeless] Before being diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, I loved hiking. I’m devastated because nothing is going to replace that. It’s all over.
357.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and curious stance
357.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Be clear when suggesting a plan of action and expectations
357.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Be positive and supportive of both big and small positive changes
357.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Appeal to relevant core learning concepts, including conditioning, reinforcement, the importance of environment, antecedents, and consequences
357.Input.res_a: I hear that it’s frustrating. And at some level you’re right; nothing else is going to perfectly “replace” what you used to do. It’s possible this expectation makes it hard to take the first step toward finding new, meaningful activities. Perhaps we can brainstorm some concrete options that would still be of interest, without any particular expectations that they would be, at least immediately, as enjoyable or meaningful as hiking?
357.Input.res_b: It's understandable to feel devastated about this significant change. However, it's important to focus on what you can still do and find new activities that bring joy and fulfillment. Let's explore other hobbies or interests that accommodate your current abilities. We can work together to adapt and discover new ways to experience satisfaction and purpose in your life.

358.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
358.Input.client_statement: [Sad, failing to make eye contact] I guess I don’t deserve better.
358.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and curious stance
358.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Be clear when suggesting a plan of action and expectations
358.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Be positive and supportive of both big and small positive changes
358.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Appeal to relevant core learning concepts, including conditioning, reinforcement, the importance of environment, antecedents, and consequences
358.Input.res_a: I notice that when you say these things, it seems hard to even make eye contact with me. I think it would be important to understand how this behavior relates to your experience in here and outside of here.
358.Input.res_b: I notice you're having a hard time looking at me while saying that. Can we explore where this idea of not deserving better comes from? What specific experiences or thoughts led you to believe this about yourself?

359.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
359.Input.client_statement: [Nervous] You’re the expert, so just tell me what to do today
359.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
359.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
359.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
359.Input.res_a: I suppose in some ways I’m the expert, but I want to avoid unilaterally dictating how we spend our time today. Further, you’re the expert on you. I have some ideas for our agenda but think it would be best to discuss and plan it together. I’m very interested in hearing your thoughts and preferences. Does this make sense?
359.Input.res_b: I appreciate your willingness to let me guide the session. However, as your therapist, my goal is to empower you to take an active role in your therapy. Can we start by identifying what you'd like to work on today? What are your top concerns or goals for our session?

360.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
360.Input.client_statement: [Hopeless] Before being diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, I loved hiking. I’m devastated because nothing is going to replace that. It’s all over.
360.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and curious stance
360.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Be clear when suggesting a plan of action and expectations
360.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Be positive and supportive of both big and small positive changes
360.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Appeal to relevant core learning concepts, including conditioning, reinforcement, the importance of environment, antecedents, and consequences
360.Input.res_a: I hear that it’s frustrating. And at some level you’re right; nothing else is going to perfectly “replace” what you used to do. It’s possible this expectation makes it hard to take the first step toward finding new, meaningful activities. Perhaps we can brainstorm some concrete options that would still be of interest, without any particular expectations that they would be, at least immediately, as enjoyable or meaningful as hiking?
360.Input.res_b: I can understand why you'd feel that way, especially given how much hiking meant to you. It's possible that your identity or sense of self has become closely tied to this activity. Let's explore this idea further. Perhaps we can brainstorm alternative activities that you might enjoy and that could bring you a similar sense of fulfillment, even if they're not exactly the same as hiking.

361.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
361.Input.client_statement: [Happy] I did what you suggested about my thoughts, and it really helped in the moment. Every time I had a negative thought, I just told myself the opposite.
361.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
361.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
361.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
361.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
361.Input.res_a: It sounds like continued practice with identifying thoughts and coming up with alternative appraisals felt helpful, and I’m glad to hear that. I might reframe this work slightly, however. Considering the opposite can be a useful place to start, and we can also expand this to considering a number of alternative appraisals or interpretations that could enhance the flexibility of our thinking. Let’s actually take an example from this past week, shall we?

However, I want to clarify that simply telling yourself the opposite of a negative thought might not be the most effective approach in the long run. Instead, let's work on identifying and challenging those negative thoughts, and then replacing them with more balanced and realistic ones. Can you tell me more about what you mean by 'telling yourself the opposite'?

362.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
362.Input.client_statement: [Frustrated] I know I said I would go to the event and start a conversation with new people, but I only managed to say “hello” to one person.

362.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Demonstrate openness to explore before determining if a modification is indeed warranted

362.Input.res_a: It seems like you might be a bit disappointed by this, but I see this as significant progress. It was a big accomplishment to show up to the event in the first place and then say hello to someone you don’t know. Let’s talk about what that was like.
362.Input.res_b: It sounds like you had a goal in mind and didn't quite meet it, which can be frustrating. Let's break it down together: what happened right before you said "hello" to that one person, and what thoughts went through your mind in that moment?

363.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
363.Input.client_statement: [Surprised] That was a really abrupt ending last session. I know we only have an hour, but I was kind of in the middle of something. That’s been on my mind ever since. I even considered not coming today . . . I guess I’ve been a little pissed off about it.

363.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Warmly invite the client to discuss their subjective experience
363.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Empathize with the clientʼs thoughts and feelings and invite further disclosure of unhelpful or invalidating occurrences
363.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: “Disarm” the clientʼs negative affect toward you or CBT by finding some truth in their disclosures

363.Input.res_a: I really appreciate you coming today and bringing this up. I bet it wasn’t easy, but it sounds like I really hurt you. You’re absolutely right that in holding us to our time, I missed the boat on what you needed. If you’re willing, I’d like to discuss this now, as it seems like a really important relationship issue for us.
363.Input.res_b: I appreciate you sharing how you felt about our last session. It’s important for me to understand when things don't feel right for you. Let’s explore what happened and address it together, ensuring we can better manage our time and not experience abrupt endings in the future. Your feedback is crucial for our progress.

364.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
364.Input.client_statement: [Dismissive] I’m not sure this is the best use of my time today.

364.Input.res_a: I think that’s important to acknowledge, and I’m glad that you’re sharing that concern with me. We want to make sure that we’re making the best use of your time. I’d like to better understand what’s behind your concerns and discuss our options for today.
364.Input.res_b: Let's explore what feels most pressing for you right now. Together, we can identify the areas that need immediate attention and prioritize them in our session. Your time is valuable, so let's make this session as productive and relevant for you as possible.

365.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
365.Input.client_statement: [Frustrated] I don’t think I can commit to coming here every week.
365.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and transparent stance
365.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Demonstrate openness to explore before determining if a modification is indeed warranted
365.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain consistency with a broad CBT orientation
365.Input.res_a: Let's explore this further. Can you tell me what's causing your frustration about committing to weekly sessions? Is it the time commitment, the cost, or something else?
365.Input.res_b: OK. Let’s consider our options, and the potential costs and benefits for your treatment. We might be able to come up with a plan that facilitates continuing to meet weekly.

366.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
366.Input.client_statement: [Helpless] I was abused when I was a child, and recently I can’t stop thinking about it. My boyfriend tries to help me be positive, but I can’t stop feeling depressed. Sometimes I think it would be easier for everyone if I was dead.
366.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Explain the logic of how CBT can be used to address concerns
366.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Instill hope for using CBT effectively
366.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Set appropriate expectations for the nature and impact of CBT
366.Input.exe: Exercise: Explaining the Treatment Rationale for Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
366.Input.res_a: I'm so sorry to hear that you're struggling with these painful memories and feelings. It's understandable that you're finding it hard to shake them off. In CBT, we believe that our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are interconnected. We'll work together to identify and challenge negative thought patterns that may be contributing to your depression. We'll also develop coping skills to help you manage these difficult emotions and memories, and work towards a more balanced and fulfilling life.
366.Input.res_b: I imagine that feels pretty overwhelming. Sometimes you think it would be easier for everyone if you were dead. I don’t want to put words in your mouth, but it sounds like there may be other times when there is still some hope—for example, the part that brought you here today. Can we examine the thought that it might be easier for everyone if you were dead?

367.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
367.Input.client_statement: [Concerned] I really need to know why I am the way I am now. I think understanding my past and childhood is really important, but it sounds like this approach doesn’t get into any of that?
367.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Explain the logic of how CBT can be used to address concerns
367.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Instill hope for using CBT effectively
367.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Set appropriate expectations for the nature and impact of CBT
367.Input.exe: Exercise: Explaining the Treatment Rationale for Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
367.Input.res_a: This is an important point of clarification. I actually agree that the past is important, and past experience is still relevant to this approach. Although we tend to focus on the present and what is going on now, your past is by no means “off limits.” In fact, we will probably need to discuss your past experiences to better understand your present life. If and when that seems most relevant, we will go there, while making sure that we connect things to what is most helpful for you now. Does that seem like a good fit for your interests?
367.Input.res_b: While it's true that CBT doesn't typically delve into the past or childhood experiences, that doesn't mean we won't acknowledge their potential impact. Our focus is on understanding how your thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are interconnected in the present moment. By identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and behaviors, we can work towards creating positive changes. Think of it like this: we're not trying to rewrite your history, but rather, help you write a more adaptive, empowering script for your present and future. Does that make sense to you?

368.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
368.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I know the job interview is going to go poorly; they always do.
368.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
368.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
368.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
368.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
368.Input.res_a: Let's explore the thought that your job interview will go poorly. What evidence do you have that supports this belief? What are some instances where things went better than you anticipated?
368.Input.res_b: How do you typically determine whether or not an interview has gone poorly? Can you think of an instance when, perhaps to your surprise, an interview didn’t go as poorly as you expected?

369.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
369.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I know I sometimes think in extremes, but what if the worst thing actually did happen? It could.
369.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
369.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
369.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
369.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
369.Input.res_a: I understand your concern, but just because something is possible doesn't mean it's probable. Let's examine the evidence for and against the worst-case scenario and work on finding a more balanced perspective that acknowledges the uncertainty without getting stuck in extremes.
369.Input.res_b: I hear you. Sometimes our biggest fears or concerns do rear their ugly head. Can you give me an example of a “worst thing”? Let’s say it did occur, what’s the absolute worst effect on you? Any sense of how you might cope?

370.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
370.Input.client_statement: [Calm] I’m not sure what to talk about today.
370.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
370.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
370.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
370.Input.res_a: OK. I have a tentative agenda for today’s session based on how we have initially framed your concerns. What if we start by reviewing that and getting your input? We might also start by reviewing the homework, seeing if that suggests any other agenda items. How does that sound?
370.Input.res_b: That's completely okay. Let's take a moment to explore what's been on your mind lately. Can you tell me about any challenges or concerns you've been experiencing since our last session? We can also review your goals and see if there's anything specific you'd like to work on today.

371.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
371.Input.client_statement: [Angry] You seem so concerned with just finishing what’s on your list before time runs out. I feel like I’m just a plug-and-play client!
371.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
371.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Empathically explore the clientʼs experience of treatment and you
371.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Validate clientsʼ experience and “roll with” versus challenging their resistance
371.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Support clientsʼ autonomy and elicit their motivation for pursuing valued directions
371.Input.res_a: I really appreciate your courage in pointing out this really important feeling. I imagine it has been painful to feel like I’ve lost you in some of the details of the work. Very importantly, I’d really like to change that.
371.Input.res_b: I'm sorry you feel that way. Your feelings are important to me, and I want to make sure we address what truly matters to you during our sessions. Let's discuss what you feel needs more attention today.

372.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
372.Input.client_statement: [Frustrated] You don’t understand. I can’t do these things because I’m depressed. If I wasn’t depressed, I could easily do these things, and I wouldn’t need to be here in the first place.
372.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and curious stance
372.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Be clear when suggesting a plan of action and expectations
372.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Be positive and supportive of both big and small positive changes
372.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Appeal to relevant core learning concepts, including conditioning, reinforcement, the importance of environment, antecedents, and consequences
372.Input.res_a: I understand that you feel like depression is holding you back, and it's true that it can make everyday tasks more challenging. However, let's explore the idea that depression doesn't define your capabilities. Can we break down the specific tasks you're struggling with and identify any small, achievable steps you can take towards accomplishing them, even if it's just a tiny step?
372.Input.res_b: I would like to understand better. It can be hard to imagine doing things when feeling so depressed, and that just further highlights the difficulty of what we’re up against. We can develop concrete strategies to help you take the initial step.

373.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
373.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I want to get a job, find a new partner, lose weight, be happier and less anxious, be more outgoing, and work on some my grief issues.
373.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation
373.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the goals and tasks
373.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize concrete, actionable, and measurable goals
373.Input.res_a: Those all sound like worthwhile goals to me. Is there a way to identify some common threads and/or prioritize one or two of these to start? I wonder if some overlap or relate to each other?
373.Input.res_b: It sounds like you have several important goals. Let's start by prioritizing them and breaking them into smaller, achievable steps. How about we focus on one or two goals to begin with?

374.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
374.Input.client_statement: [Angry] You don’t understand. I want to stop feeling sad, not practice feeling sad. I’m already pretty freaking great at feeling bad. So, I really don’t need more practice at that!
374.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Empathically inquire about clientsʼ emotional experience
374.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Actively listen and maintain a supportive tone to clientsʼ emotional disclosures
374.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Model tolerance of affect and an approach orientation to clientsʼ strong emotional experience
374.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Use psychoeducation to support the importance of clients experiencing versus avoiding their emotion and the maladaptive consequences of negative reinforcement
374.Input.res_a: I’m really glad you told me how this feels for you! It sounds like I really missed the boat here and haven’t been understanding what you’ve been telling me. I apologize. It must have been very frustrating to come in here every week and feel like you’re doing the opposite of what you want to accomplish. I’m wondering if we can talk about this more and figure out a solution together?
374.Input.res_b: It sounds like you're feeling frustrated with the idea of practicing emotional regulation, particularly with sadness. I understand that it can feel counterintuitive to intentionally engage with an emotion you're trying to avoid. However, the goal of our work isn't to induce or prolong negative emotions, but rather to develop skills to manage them effectively when they arise. We can work together to find ways to practice emotional regulation that feel more empowering and less like 'practicing sadness'.

375.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
375.Input.client_statement: [Confused] I’m not sure I understand how talking about my feelings will help.
375.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Explain the logic of how CBT can be used to address concerns
375.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Instill hope for using CBT effectively
375.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Set appropriate expectations for the nature and impact of CBT
375.Input.exe: Exercise: Explaining the Treatment Rationale for Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
375.Input.res_a: This is very common concern, and I appreciate you sharing it. Our intention won’t be to talk about your feelings simply for the sake of talking about your feelings. Rather, we want to help you experience your feelings in new ways. This will help you reflect on them more objectively and respond to them in a more adaptive way to get your needs met and live the type of life that you want to live.
375.Input.res_b: Let me clarify how cognitive-behavioral therapy works. We won't just be talking about your feelings, but rather exploring how your thoughts, feelings, and actions are interconnected. By identifying and challenging negative thought patterns, we can work together to develop more balanced and constructive ways of thinking, which can lead to improved emotions and behaviors. This process can help you develop skills to manage your symptoms and improve your overall well-being. Does that make sense?

376.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
376.Input.client_statement: [Sad] I think our sessions have been very helpful. However, my depression is getting worse. On my drive to this session today. I pictured myself driving off a bridge. It honestly felt like a relief to imagine not having to work so hard to feel better anymore.
376.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
376.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
376.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
376.Input.res_a: I'm so glad you shared this with me, and I'm concerned about the intensity of your feelings. Before we explore this further, I want to acknowledge your courage in sharing such a difficult thought. Can we prioritize your safety in our agenda for today and work together to develop a plan to keep you safe?

This approach allows us to focus on the most pressing issues and make the most of our time together.

We won't be dwelling on past traumas unless you feel comfortable and ready to do so. My goal is to empower you with skills and strategies to manage your thoughts and emotions in a safe and controlled environment. I'll work with you to establish a pace that feels comfortable for you, and we can always adjust our approach as needed.

401.Input.res_a: Welcome to our session! I'm glad you're taking this first step. In cognitive behavioral therapy, we'll work together to identify and understand the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that contribute to your distress. We'll focus on specific issues you're struggling with and develop strategies to address them. Our goal is to help you learn new skills and ways of thinking to improve your mental health and well-being. Would you like to start by sharing what brings you here today?
401.Input.res_b: We’ll likely talk about a variety of things. Ultimately, we want to focus on what’s most important to you. We’ll set goals for treatment; I’ll teach you skills for noticing and modifying thoughts and behaviors; you’ll do homework to practice; we’ll set an agenda at the beginning of each session and take up concrete, specific things you want help with; and we’ll monitor progress as we proceed, making adjustments if we do not get the progress we want.
