427.Input.res_b: It sounds like you're feeling hopeful about this new medication. It's great to explore all options. How about we discuss this further and assess if it's a good fit for you? Also, let’s continue working on building coping strategies to give you multiple tools to manage anxiety.

428.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
428.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Empathically inquire about clientsʼ emotional experience
428.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Actively listen and maintain a supportive tone to clientsʼ emotional disclosures
428.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Model tolerance of affect and an approach orientation to clientsʼ strong emotional experience
428.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Use psychoeducation to support the importance of clients experiencing versus avoiding their emotion and the maladaptive consequences of negative reinforcement
428.Input.res_a: Take your time, it's okay to feel overwhelmed. Can you take a deep breath and try to put into words what's going through your mind?
428.Input.res_b: [Silence; allow client to cry and simply be present with an engaged nod and gaze. Do not speak first or shut down the emotion experiencing.]

429.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
429.Input.client_statement: [Curious] I’m not sure about an agenda. With my other therapist, I just kind of talked about whatever was on my mind.
429.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
429.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
429.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
429.Input.res_a: Yes, some therapies are less structured than others. The approach that we’re taking is more on the structured side. Regardless, I want to make sure that we focus on the things that are most important to you. In my experience, it can be helpful to do this in the context of a general plan connected to your goals to keep things on track and continue to move our work forward. If it’s OK with you, I’d like to hear more about your thoughts about being more structured in here.
429.Input.res_b: It's completely normal to have different experiences with therapy and to wonder what to expect from our sessions together. In CBT, we work collaboratively to identify specific goals and areas you'd like to focus on during our time together. I'd like to propose we set a general agenda for our sessions, but not a rigid one. This will allow us to explore topics that are important to you while also ensuring we make progress towards your goals. How does that sound to you?

430.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
430.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I don’t think I want to do any exposure.
430.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation
430.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the goals and tasks
430.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize concrete, actionable, and measurable goals
430.Input.res_a: I hear that. If it’s OK with you, we can spend some time talking about what exposure work would look like and discuss your concerns. We also have other options to discuss.
430.Input.res_b: Let's take a step back and explore what's making you hesitant about exposure. What specific concerns or fears come up for you when you think about confronting your anxieties?

431.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
431.Input.client_statement: [Nervous] My partner wants us to talk about something today.
431.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
431.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
431.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
431.Input.res_a: Can you tell me a bit more about what your partner wants to discuss? It might be helpful to explore what you're hoping to get out of the conversation and what concerns you may have about discussing this topic.
431.Input.res_b: OK. I’d like to hear more about that, and, most important, if this is something that you want us to put on the agenda today. Perhaps we can visit that after we review what you’ve been working on over the past week?

432.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
432.Input.client_statement: [Impatient] Wait a minute . . . you’re saying if I can’t fall asleep, then I need to get out of bed and stop trying to sleep?
432.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and curious stance
432.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Be clear when suggesting a plan of action and expectations
432.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Be positive and supportive of both big and small positive changes
432.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Appeal to relevant core learning concepts, including conditioning, reinforcement, the importance of environment, antecedents, and consequences
432.Input.res_a: Let's break this down. The idea is not to stop trying to sleep altogether, but rather to change your approach. Instead of lying in bed, feeling frustrated and awake, you can try engaging in a relaxing activity in a different room, like reading a book or listening to soothing music, to help calm your mind and body before returning to bed when you feel more relaxed.
432.Input.res_b: Yes, and that might sound counterintuitive. It’s important for the bed and bedroom to be specifically associated with sleep. The reality is that you aren’t sleeping anyway. When you leave the bedroom and come back when you are ready for sleep, you train your brain to learn that the bed is the place for sleep.

433.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
433.Input.client_statement: [Angry] You don’t understand. I want to stop feeling sad, not practice feeling sad. I’m already pretty freaking great at feeling bad. So, I really don’t need more practice at that!
433.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Empathically inquire about clientsʼ emotional experience
433.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Actively listen and maintain a supportive tone to clientsʼ emotional disclosures
433.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Model tolerance of affect and an approach orientation to clientsʼ strong emotional experience
433.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Use psychoeducation to support the importance of clients experiencing versus avoiding their emotion and the maladaptive consequences of negative reinforcement
433.Input.res_a: I’m really glad you told me how this feels for you! It sounds like I really missed the boat here and haven’t been understanding what you’ve been telling me. I apologize. It must have been very frustrating to come in here every week and feel like you’re doing the opposite of what you want to accomplish. I’m wondering if we can talk about this more and figure out a solution together?
433.Input.res_b: I hear you’re feeling frustrated and angry. Remember, we’re not practicing feeling sad; we’re learning to understand and manage those emotions differently. By acknowledging and exploring your sadness, we can identify unhelpful thought patterns and work on strategies to break the cycle, ultimately helping you feel better in the long run. It’s about gaining control, not just experiencing the sadness.

434.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
434.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Explain the logic of how CBT can be used to address concerns
434.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Instill hope for using CBT effectively
434.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Set appropriate expectations for the nature and impact of CBT
434.Input.exe: Exercise: Explaining the Treatment Rationale for Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
434.Input.res_a: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, or CBT, is a problem-focused approach that helps you understand how your thoughts, feelings, and actions are interconnected. Through our work together, we'll identify and challenge negative thought patterns, learn new coping skills, and develop more adaptive ways of thinking and behaving to improve your mental well-being.
434.Input.res_b: That’s a great question! In cognitive behavioral therapy, we’ll be looking at your cognitions—that is, your thoughts and your behaviors—to identify whether I can teach you some skills for managing them that will help you address some of the problems you are wanting help with. Does that help answer your question?

435.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
435.Input.client_statement: [Curious] Geez. I don’t even know where to start in picturing my happiness.
435.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation
435.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the goals and tasks
435.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize concrete, actionable, and measurable goals
435.Input.res_a: It's great that you're curious! Let's begin by identifying small, specific areas in your life that you enjoy or wish to improve. We can then set attainable goals to move towards your larger vision of happiness.
435.Input.res_b: I can appreciate that. Perhaps we can start by narrowing the focus a bit. How will we know if you’re happier, say, one month from now? What would be a good indication of that?

436.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
436.Input.client_statement: [Frustrated] I don’t know... when things get intense, I just act. I don’t have any thoughts; I just act or react.
436.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
436.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
436.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
436.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
436.Input.res_a: I see. It happens so quickly that you just react. It’s true that the thoughts connected to our emotions and behaviors aren’t always so clear or explicit. Yet if we train ourselves to step back for a moment and work backward from your reaction, I wonder if we might notice your thinking. In doing so, we might get a better sense of why you feel the way you do in these moments.
436.Input.res_b: It sounds like you're feeling like you're operating on autopilot when things get overwhelming. That can be really challenging. In CBT, we often talk about the idea that our thoughts, feelings, and actions are interconnected. So, even if you're not consciously thinking about it, your brain is likely processing information and making decisions in the background. Let's explore this idea further. Can you tell me more about what you mean by "acting" or "reacting" in those intense moments?

437.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
437.Input.client_statement: [Curious] I’m still trying to get the hang of identifying my thoughts. Should I plan for anything next week?
437.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Provide a basic rationale for the homework assignment
437.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Tailor the homework assignment to the clientʼs concerns and needs
437.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Ensure that there is adequate agreement on and understanding of the homework assignment
437.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Encourage and validate good-faith efforts
437.Input.exe: Exercise: Assigning and Reviewing Between-Session Activities
437.Input.res_a: Let's review the between-session activities we discussed last week. To help you solidify your thought-identification skills, I recommend continuing to practice daily thought records. Set aside a specific time each day to write down any negative thoughts that come up, and bring them to our next session to review.
437.Input.res_b: Sure, I hear you are still learning to identify your thoughts. Here’s an idea: If I give you a thought record, would you be able to focus on an upsetting situation and write down the emotions and thoughts you have in that situation, just like we’ve done in here together?

438.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
438.Input.client_statement: [Irritated] Well, I guess the homework you’re suggesting makes some sense, but I’m also easily irritated lately . . . especially when things are unclear for me and when they’re overwhelming.
438.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
438.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Warmly invite the client to discuss their subjective experience
438.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Empathize with the clientʼs thoughts and feelings and invite further disclosure of unhelpful or invalidating occurrences
438.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: “Disarm” the clientʼs negative affect toward you or CBT by finding some truth in their disclosures
438.Input.exe: Exercise: Responding to Therapeutic Alliance Ruptures
438.Input.res_a: It seems that what’s frustrating to you is not only that the homework is unclear, but perhaps that I’ve asked you to do too much. This is definitely a misstep on my part, and I’d really like to work together to find activities that are clear and not overwhelming. Can we discuss that together today?
438.Input.res_b: I appreciate your honesty about feeling irritated. It sounds like the homework may be adding to your sense of overwhelm. Can we break it down together to make it more manageable and clarify any unclear aspects? I want to ensure our work together feels collaborative and supportive, not overwhelming.

439.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
439.Input.client_statement: [Sad, withdrawn] I just don’t know what to say or do anymore . . . to you—or anyone.
439.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
439.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Warmly invite the client to discuss their subjective experience
439.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Empathize with the clientʼs thoughts and feelings and invite further disclosure of unhelpful or invalidating occurrences
439.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: “Disarm” the clientʼs negative affect toward you or CBT by finding some truth in their disclosures
439.Input.exe: Exercise: Responding to Therapeutic Alliance Ruptures
439.Input.res_a: I sense a feeling of disconnection and helplessness. Can you help me understand what's led you to feel this way, perhaps something I've done or said that's contributed to your feeling stuck and unsure about how to proceed in our sessions?
439.Input.res_b: That sounds really hard, like being at your wit’s end. Can you help me understand what it feels like for you? I’m really invested in understanding your experience so that we can get on the same page of how to use our time effectively.

440.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
440.Input.client_statement: [Calm] I just want to be happier.
440.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation
440.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the goals and tasks
440.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize concrete, actionable, and measurable goals
440.Input.res_a: To work towards becoming happier, let's break it down further. Can you think of specific situations, activities, or areas in your life where you feel unhappy or unfulfilled, and what would make you feel more satisfied or joyful in those moments?
440.Input.res_b: Being happier sounds like a reasonable goal to me. I wonder, though, if we can break it down a bit into something more concrete. For example, what would it look like to be happier? How, precisely, might your life be different?

441.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
441.Input.client_statement: [Nervous] I have a hard time with organization, so I’m worried about doing all of the homework correctly.
441.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Explain the logic of how CBT can be used to address concerns
441.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Instill hope for using CBT effectively
441.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Set appropriate expectations for the nature and impact of CBT
441.Input.exe: Exercise: Explaining the Treatment Rationale for Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
441.Input.res_a: I understand your concern and would like, first, to clarify the exact nature of it. In general, before we send you out the door with an assignment, we’ll spend some time thinking about what might make it hard for you to do and figure out a strategy or two to help with that. How does that sound?
441.Input.res_b: It’s normal to feel concerned about the homework. Remember, the goal of CBT is to help you identify and change patterns contributing to your difficulties. We'll tackle the homework step-by-step together, and I'll offer guidance. Your effort is what's most important, and we'll adjust as needed. You're not alone in this process.

442.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
442.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I want to get a job, find a new partner, lose weight, be happier and less anxious, be more outgoing, and work on some my grief issues.
442.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation
442.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the goals and tasks
442.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize concrete, actionable, and measurable goals
442.Input.res_a: Those all sound like worthwhile goals to me. Is there a way to identify some common threads and/or prioritize one or two of these to start? I wonder if some overlap or relate to each other?
442.Input.res_b: It sounds like you have a lot of goals in mind. Let's prioritize them together. Which one or two goals feel most important to you right now, and what small steps can we take to start working towards them?

443.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
443.Input.client_statement: [Nervous] I don’t think I’m ready to work on this today.
443.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Empathically inquire about clientsʼ emotional experience
443.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Actively listen and maintain a supportive tone to clientsʼ emotional disclosures
443.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Model tolerance of affect and an approach orientation to clientsʼ strong emotional experience
443.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Use psychoeducation to support the importance of clients experiencing versus avoiding their emotion and the maladaptive consequences of negative reinforcement
443.Input.res_a: OK. It sounds like there’s some uncertainty about moving forward with this today. Let’s discuss your concerns. Some degree of anxiety is always expected—and part of the point, right? But this isn’t easy. We can also revisit the plan for today.
443.Input.res_b: It's completely normal to feel apprehensive when exploring challenging emotions. Can you tell me more about what's making you feel unready? Is it the topic itself or something else that's causing your hesitation?

444.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
444.Input.client_statement: [Impatient] I think there’s a problem with my brain and I might just need medication.
444.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation
444.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the goals and tasks
444.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize concrete, actionable, and measurable goals
444.Input.res_a: Some people with similar problems do benefit from medication, or a combination of CBT and medication. Although biology is important, I’m not sure I’d frame this as a problem with your brain. Even if we did stipulate this, CBT can also change your brain. Shall we spend a few minutes discussing your options?
444.Input.res_b: I understand your frustration, but let's not jump to conclusions. Before considering medication, let's explore what specific issues you're struggling with and how they're impacting your life. What are some changes you'd like to see in yourself or your life that would indicate progress or success to you?

445.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
445.Input.client_statement: [Ambivalent] Well, I went to do the homework, but then it occurred to me that I shouldn’t try to reduce my worry too much. I mean it’s stressful, but there are times it actually helps me stay on top of things . . . to be accountable.
445.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
445.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Empathically explore the clientʼs experience of treatment and you
445.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Validate clientsʼ experience and “roll with” versus challenging their resistance
445.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Support clientsʼ autonomy and elicit their motivation for pursuing valued directions
445.Input.res_a: First, I appreciate you sharing this, as I imagine it wasn’t easy. Second, it must be difficult to hold such competing feelings simultaneously. On the one hand, a lot of worrying stinks, but, on the other, it can also serve a purpose. That seems to put you in a bind, and maybe we’ve been ignoring the side of you that sort of values your worrying. Does that fit your experience?
445.Input.res_b: I understand your concern that worry might serve a purpose for you. It's great that you're thinking critically about this. However, let's also consider the costs of excessive worry. How does it impact your daily life and relationships? Are there other, more effective ways to stay accountable and on top of things without relying on worry? Let's explore this further and weigh the pros and cons together.

446.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
446.Input.client_statement: [Nervous] My partner wants us to talk about something today.
446.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
446.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
446.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
446.Input.res_a: OK. I’d like to hear more about that, and, most important, if this is something that you want us to put on the agenda today. Perhaps we can visit that after we review what you’ve been working on over the past week?
446.Input.res_b: It sounds like this is making you nervous. Let's take a moment to discuss what your partner wants to talk about and plan our session to address it. We can make sure you're comfortable and prepared for that conversation.

447.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
447.Input.client_statement: [Sad] I was feeling hopeless and didn’t want to come in today.
447.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
447.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
447.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
447.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
447.Input.res_a: What was going through your mind when you noticed feeling hopeless? What ultimately led to your coming?
447.Input.res_b: It sounds like the negative thoughts about the session were overwhelming and making it hard to muster the motivation to come in.

448.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
448.Input.client_statement: [Angry] I don’t think you really care about me! You just pretend to like me because it’s your job!
448.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Empathically inquire about clientsʼ emotional experience
448.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Actively listen and maintain a supportive tone to clientsʼ emotional disclosures
448.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Model tolerance of affect and an approach orientation to clientsʼ strong emotional experience
448.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Use psychoeducation to support the importance of clients experiencing versus avoiding their emotion and the maladaptive consequences of negative reinforcement
448.Input.res_a: I understand that it can be frustrating to feel like you're not being genuinely heard. However, I want to assure you that my goal is to help you, not just pretend to care. Can we explore what specifically led you to feel this way about our sessions?
448.Input.res_b: You’re right: This is my job. It’s OK to question other people’s motives, including mine, and to feel upset with me if I conveyed that I only pretend to be invested in you and your treatment. Can we discuss what’s contributing to these doubts about whether I genuinely care about you?

449.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
449.Input.client_statement: [Withdrawn] I’m not sure where to start, or what to prioritize on today’s agenda. Sorry.
449.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
449.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Warmly invite the client to discuss their subjective experience
449.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Empathize with the clientʼs thoughts and feelings and invite further disclosure of unhelpful or invalidating occurrences
449.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: “Disarm” the clientʼs negative affect toward you or CBT by finding some truth in their disclosures
449.Input.exe: Exercise: Responding to Therapeutic Alliance Ruptures
449.Input.res_a: Oh, I see. Putting agendas aside for a moment, I’m having a sense that you are somewhat distant me from today . . . less engaged than typical. Is that your sense too?
449.Input.res_b: No need to apologize. It's completely normal to feel uncertain. Can we take a step back and explore what's making it hard for you to decide where to start today?

450.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
450.Input.client_statement: [Nervous] I guess I was expecting that we’d just talk about whatever came to my mind on a given week.
450.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest CBT-consistent goals and tasks that align with an individualized CBT case formulation
450.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the goals and tasks
450.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize concrete, actionable, and measurable goals
450.Input.res_a: We do want to prioritize what’s most important for you. In fact, we’ll work together today to develop a general road map for your therapy, while collaboratively establishing an agenda each session. We might find that some recurring themes emerge and drive our work (more so than just what comes to mind). Does that make sense?
450.Input.res_b: It's completely normal to feel that way. In CBT, we often focus on specific goals to make our sessions more effective. Identifying your goals can help us address the issues that matter most to you and make meaningful progress. What’s something important you’d like to work on?

451.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
451.Input.client_statement: [Angry] You’re telling me that if my partner died, I should be fine with it?!
451.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
451.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
451.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
451.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
451.Input.res_a: I'm not saying you should be fine with it. Losing a partner is a significant loss, and it's normal to feel pain and grief. What I'm trying to help you with is identifying any unhelpful thinking patterns that may be intensifying your distress. For example, are you having any catastrophic thoughts or self-criticisms that are making it harder for you to cope with the idea of this potential loss? Let's explore these thoughts together and see if we can reframe them in a more balanced way.
451.Input.res_b: Oh, my goodness; no. I’m so sorry I was unclear. Let me try again. If we’re tracking your experience, we can identify the situation “my partner died”; thoughts such as “This is horrible. My life is over, I’ll never be happy again. I’ll be alone forever”; and emotions of pain, grief, loss, hopelessness, helplessness. . . . OK, so now here is the question I have for you. Let’s focus on these emotions. What is causing you to have them? Is it the situation? Or is it the thoughts?

452.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
452.Input.client_statement: [Irritated] The agenda sounds fine, I suppose. I don’t know. I don’t think this is working, so I’m not sure it matters.
452.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
452.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
452.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
452.Input.res_a: Can you help me understand what you mean by 'this isn't working'? What specific aspects of our sessions or the agenda aren't meeting your expectations? Let's discuss and see if we can make adjustments to better suit your needs.
452.Input.res_b: That’s really important, and I’m glad you’re sharing these concerns with me. I suggest we put that issue on our agenda today—explore your concerns about therapy and what is contributing to this sense that it isn’t “working.” Is that OK with you?

453.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
453.Input.client_statement: [Apprehensive] I successfully did the homework! However, it made me very nervous, so I had a few drinks beforehand. This is OK, right? I hope you don’t judge my drinking, like my wife and boss do.
453.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Provide a basic rationale for the homework assignment
453.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Tailor the homework assignment to the clientʼs concerns and needs
453.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Ensure that there is adequate agreement on and understanding of the homework assignment
453.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Encourage and validate good-faith efforts
453.Input.exe: Exercise: Assigning and Reviewing Between-Session Activities
453.Input.res_a: I appreciate that you shared this with me. It sounds like others have expressed concern about your drinking, and you’re wondering if I might share that concern. Rather than labeling what happened as “OK” or “not OK,” I’d rather discuss your experience of completing the homework and how drinking beforehand does or does not fit in with the spirit of the work you’re during between our sessions. I’d also like to hear more about your impression that others, perhaps even me, are judging you for your drinking and the impact that seems to have on you.
453.Input.res_b: It's great to hear that you were able to complete the homework, and that's a significant accomplishment. However, I want to explore the underlying feelings that led you to have a few drinks beforehand. It seems like you're worried about how others might perceive this, and that's causing you anxiety. Let's break this down together: what do you think is the primary concern here - is it the drinking itself, or the fear of being judged?

454.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
454.Input.client_statement: [Weeping] I just don’t think I can do this homework on my own.
454.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Provide a basic rationale for the homework assignment
454.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Tailor the homework assignment to the clientʼs concerns and needs
454.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Ensure that there is adequate agreement on and understanding of the homework assignment
454.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Encourage and validate good-faith efforts
454.Input.exe: Exercise: Assigning and Reviewing Between-Session Activities
454.Input.res_a: It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed. Can you tell me more about what specifically is making you feel like you can't do the homework on your own? Is it the task itself, or is it something else? We can break it down together and see if there's a way to make it feel more manageable. Remember, the goal of these exercises is to help you develop skills and confidence, not to add more stress.
454.Input.res_b: It sounds like you’re concerned about trying this on your own. We can take a few minutes to clear up anything that might be confusing logistically. Let’s go into the details of the assignment to see how we can set something up that is more doable for you. It’s also important to emphasize that this isn’t something that you’re either going to “pass” or “fail.” The process is just as, or even more, important than the outcome.

455.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
455.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I know the job interview is going to go poorly; they always do.
455.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
455.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
455.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
455.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
455.Input.res_a: How do you typically determine whether or not an interview has gone poorly? Can you think of an instance when, perhaps to your surprise, an interview didn’t go as poorly as you expected?
455.Input.res_b: Let's examine the evidence for that thought. What specific experiences are you basing this prediction on, and are there any exceptions or times when interviews went better than expected?

456.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
456.Input.client_statement: [Angry] My partner cheated on me. And, no, there is no alternative explanation, so stop asking that! He cheated, so our relationship was a lie!
456.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Momentarily step away from the CBT change agenda
456.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Warmly invite the client to discuss their subjective experience
456.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Empathize with the clientʼs thoughts and feelings and invite further disclosure of unhelpful or invalidating occurrences
456.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: “Disarm” the clientʼs negative affect toward you or CBT by finding some truth in their disclosures
456.Input.exe: Exercise: Responding to Therapeutic Alliance Ruptures
456.Input.res_a: I understand your hurt and anger. It sounds like you're feeling invalidated by my questions. Can we explore how that's affecting our work together?
456.Input.res_b: I can feel that you’re very angry at me right now. My words must have hurt you; can you tell me more about this?

457.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
457.Input.client_statement: [Nervous] I don’t think I’m ready for working on this today.
457.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
457.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
457.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
457.Input.res_a: That's okay. We can take it at your pace. Let's discuss what makes you feel nervous and perhaps identify a smaller step or another focus that feels more manageable for today.
457.Input.res_b: OK. We can revisit and possibly modify our plan for today. How about we first take a step back and explore your thinking about this? What thoughts are you noticing as we discuss the agenda?

458.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
458.Input.client_statement: [Frustrated] I don’t like this breathing stuff. The experience monitoring was more helpful.
458.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and transparent stance
458.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Demonstrate openness to explore before determining if a modification is indeed warranted
458.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain consistency with a broad CBT orientation
458.Input.res_a: OK. Each person is different, and some things are experienced as more helpful than others. I’d like to hear more about what you don’t like about the breathing work. We can certainly adjust to focus more on the experience monitoring if that is more helpful.
458.Input.res_b: It seems like you found the breathing exercises less engaging and more challenging than the experience monitoring aspect of our session. Can you tell me more about what specifically didn't work for you about the breathing exercises?

459.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
459.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
459.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance

459.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
459.Input.res_a: Let’s focus on that thought. I wonder what you might say to a friend who told you something similar?
459.Input.res_b: Let's break down that thought together. What does "total failure" mean to you, and how did you come to that conclusion?

460.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
460.Input.client_statement: [Frustrated] I don’t think I can commit to coming here every week.
460.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and transparent stance
460.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Demonstrate openness to explore before determining if a modification is indeed warranted
460.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain consistency with a broad CBT orientation
460.Input.res_a: Let's explore what's making it hard for you to commit. Is it the frequency, the time of day, or something else that's causing you distress about our sessions?
460.Input.res_b: OK. Let’s consider our options, and the potential costs and benefits for your treatment. We might be able to come up with a plan that facilitates continuing to meet weekly.

461.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
461.Input.client_statement: [Curious] So, what’s our agenda for today?
461.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
461.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
461.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
461.Input.res_a: Let's take a look at what we can cover in our session today. Based on our previous discussions, I'd like to start by reviewing your goals and objectives for our therapy. We can also discuss any new challenges or issues that have arisen since our last session. Additionally, we can work on developing a plan to tackle some of the specific problems you've been facing. If there's anything specific you'd like to focus on or any new topics you'd like to explore, please let me know and we can adjust the agenda accordingly.
461.Input.res_b: Let’s start by figuring that out together, OK? I was thinking that we would begin by reviewing your experience with the homework over the past week, including any questions that came up for you. That should then be a nice segue to something I’d like to introduce and practice a bit in here today. We can spend most of the session on that and then save some time to make a plan for the next week. Of course, I also want to make sure that we budget time for anything else that you’d like to discuss today. Is there anything you’d like to add?

462.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
462.Input.client_statement: [Dismissive] I didn’t do the homework. It didn’t seem like it was that important, to be honest.
462.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Provide a basic rationale for the homework assignment
462.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Tailor the homework assignment to the clientʼs concerns and needs
462.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Ensure that there is adequate agreement on and understanding of the homework assignment
462.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Encourage and validate good-faith efforts
462.Input.exe: Exercise: Assigning and Reviewing Between-Session Activities
462.Input.res_a: I understand that the homework may not have seemed important to you, but it's a crucial part of our therapy process. Can you help me understand what got in the way of completing the assignment? Was there something specific that made it seem unimportant or overwhelming?
462.Input.res_b: OK, well that seems important to me. Can we talk about that? Were you having doubts when we discussed this last session, or only after you thought about it more? In the end, we need to value the goals and tasks we are doing for them to bear fruit.

463.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
463.Input.client_statement: [Shaking and weeping] This is not something I can get into without hysterically crying. That’s why I avoid it.
463.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Empathically inquire about clientsʼ emotional experience
463.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Actively listen and maintain a supportive tone to clientsʼ emotional disclosures
463.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Model tolerance of affect and an approach orientation to clientsʼ strong emotional experience
463.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Use psychoeducation to support the importance of clients experiencing versus avoiding their emotion and the maladaptive consequences of negative reinforcement
463.Input.res_a: It sounds like those emotions are very intense for you, and it's understandable that you'd want to avoid discomfort. Let's take small steps to address this. We can start by working on ways to manage your anxiety and tears, gradually exploring these feelings in a safe space at your own pace. Techniques like deep breathing, mindfulness, and grounding exercises can help. Remember, it’s perfectly okay to feel emotional, and we’ll work together to make this process manageable for you.
463.Input.res_b: Yes, I totally get it. And, like we discussed, avoiding it brings temporary relief. But, often at a longer term cost. By avoiding something to feel relief, it’s like we tell ourselves that “this is too big and powerful for me to deal with in any other way,” which only strengthens the narrative and the emotion, giving it more control over you. Does that make sense? Do you remain motivated to see that we can lessen such power, even if it means tolerating discomfort to get there?

464.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
464.Input.client_statement: [Frustrated] To be honest, the last couple of sessions I’ve been confused by our focus on my challenges. My family says I should just stay positive, smile more, and not think about anything negative. Do we have to discuss my challenges?
464.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Suggest a CBT-consistent agenda that aligns with the CBT case formulation
464.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Invite the clientʼs input on and agreement with the agenda
464.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain some degree of frame or structure (i.e., the agenda can shift, but generally maintain a more or less explicit attempt to delineate expectations for session goals and tasks)
464.Input.res_a: We aim to address your challenges to understand and manage them better, which can lead to more lasting positive changes. While staying positive is important, discussing difficulties helps in developing coping strategies. Let's set an agenda that balances your concerns and the focus on positivity.
464.Input.res_b: I see. You’re bringing up an important point. I agree that it’s important to also focus on strengths and be mindful of and build on what is positive, so this is helpful feedback. I also wonder about your perspective on this. How about we put this issue on our agenda today?

465.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
465.Input.client_statement: [Tearing up] I don’t even know if I’m getting any better in here. I mean, I’ve been in therapy for weeks and I feel the same.
465.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Empathically inquire about clientsʼ emotional experience
465.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Actively listen and maintain a supportive tone to clientsʼ emotional disclosures
465.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Model tolerance of affect and an approach orientation to clientsʼ strong emotional experience
465.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Use psychoeducation to support the importance of clients experiencing versus avoiding their emotion and the maladaptive consequences of negative reinforcement
465.Input.res_a: It sounds like you're feeling frustrated and uncertain about the progress you're making in our sessions. I want you to know that it's completely normal to feel this way, especially when we're working through complex emotions and issues. Progress in therapy can be slow and non-linear, and it's not always easy to see immediate results. Can you tell me what you think would make you feel like you're getting better, and what specific changes you're hoping to see in our sessions?
465.Input.res_b: If you feel you aren’t making progress, that’s important. Let’s revisit your goals and see what we think about progress. If you aren’t making the progress you want, we can do some brainstorming about how to enhance or change your treatment to get more progress. How does that sound to you? Or, another option is we could do a thought record to identify what thoughts you are having to cause you to feel so hopeless. Which of these do you want to do?

466.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
466.Input.client_statement: [Anxious] I don’t think I’m ready to do all of what you’re asking me to do before the next session.
466.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Maintain a collaborative and transparent stance
466.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Demonstrate openness to explore before determining if a modification is indeed warranted
466.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Maintain consistency with a broad CBT orientation
466.Input.res_a: Thanks for letting me know. Let’s figure out something that will be more manageable and helpful for you.
466.Input.res_b: That's okay. Let's break the tasks into smaller steps and focus on what feels manageable for you.

467.Title: Pairwise comparison for CBT deliberate practice
467.Input.client_statement: [Angry] I don’t like this or find it helpful. My thoughts aren’t irrational or baseless, so I actually find it kind of invalidating and insulting.
467.Input.cr_1: Criteria 1: Encourage and facilitate client self-reflection on thoughts and beliefs
467.Input.cr_2: Criteria 2: Maintain an open, exploratory stance
467.Input.cr_3: Criteria 3: Orient the clientʼs attention to thoughts or connections between thoughts and other experiences
467.Input.cr_4: Criteria 4: Emphasize cognitive flexibility, rather than simple thought replacement, and refrain from implying that a particular thought is “right or wrong
467.Input.res_a: I appreciate you sharing this understandable feeling. It would be invalidating to have someone (including me) label your thoughts as irrational and baseless. To be sure, I’d like us both to assume that there is a way to understand the genuine bases of your thinking patterns, and how these are connected with other parts of your experience. Would you be open to exploring in more detail an example of when it felt like I was implying that your thoughts are invalid or baseless and work to find out what was contributing to that experience?
467.Input.res_b: I understand that you feel strongly about this, and it's natural to feel defensive when our thoughts and perceptions are challenged. However, in CBT, we're not trying to label your thoughts as irrational or invalid. Instead, we're exploring how they might be contributing to your distress and whether there are alternative perspectives that could be helpful. Can you tell me more about what specifically feels invalidating or insulting about this process? What are you hoping to get out of our sessions?
